commit_message:
Default video type to 'vga' for PowerKVM

PowerKVM currently doesn't support 'cirrus' video type. For now, we can
detect if Nova compute is running on ppc64 or ppc architecture systems
and set the default to 'vga', which is supported on PowerKVM.

This patch did some reordering of the logic in
nova.virt.libvirt.driver.LibvirtDriver.get_guest_config in an attempt to
set the video.type depending on the compute host architecture and
implementation specifics. The video.type can still be set using
image_meta.

Change-Id: I49a1a8e6d9ebdc28d876d2f958c8cb960892f322
Closes-Bug: 1274367

documentation in api-site currently has to be manually fixed.

commit_message:
Refactor _create_template to not rely on instances

The core of the _create_template logic in autoscaling.py is now in
a separate static method, _resource_templates. _resource_templates is
destined to be moved to another scaling module that is intended to
be used outside of the heat engine, so it won't have access to instance
objects.

Implements: partial blueprint as-lib

Change-Id: I0eda024c88534207daa71de2a8eb53738cdd89ef

added_lines: Create a template to represent autoscaled instances. Also see _resource_templates. """ instance_definition = self._get_instance_definition() old_resources = [(instance.name, instance.t) for instance in self.get_instances()[-num_instances:]] templates = self._resource_templates( old_resources, instance_definition, num_instances, num_replace) return {"Resources": dict(templates)} @staticmethod def _resource_templates(old_resources, resource_definition, num_resources, num_replace): """ num_create = num_resources - len(old_resources) for i in range(num_resources): if i < len(old_resources): old_name, old_template = old_resources[i] if old_template != resource_definition and num_replace > 0: yield old_name, resource_definition else: yield old_name, old_template else: yield short_id.generate_id(), resource_definition return list(instance_templates(num_replace))
deleted_lines: instances = self.get_instances()[-num_instances:] instance_definition = self._get_instance_definition() num_create = num_instances - len(instances) for i in range(num_instances): if i < len(instances): inst = instances[i] if inst.t != instance_definition and num_replace > 0: yield inst.name, instance_definition else: yield inst.name, inst.t else: yield short_id.generate_id(), instance_definition return {"Resources": dict(instance_templates(num_replace))}

commit_message:
FIX: L23network module can't get one-element array as bond parameter

Because Pupet convert one-element array of strings to string.

Closes bug: #1277147

Change-Id: I86db13a0a7d3df7aa93a38889313ff636149ea79

commit_message:
Add a suitable default for '-b'

Most OpenStack doc projects contain only one book anyway, thus use the
first book found in ./doc/ as the default.

Avoids an unhelpful exception if -b is not specified.

Change-Id: I103ddbcf2cb0b3781926896ae78a26ed86b74257
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-doc-tools refs/changes/87/71487/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: "-b", "--book", dest="book", help=("specified docbook")

subject: Don't copy the flavorid when updating flavors
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-04 23:16:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/91ea4acc00083043b4503d3cf20e4050fb70d64a', 'message': 'Don't copy the flavorid when updating flavors

The Nova API makes the implicit assumption that flavorids are unique,
so if one creates two flavors with the same flavorid, subsequent
requests for flavor information can vary between "inaccurate" and
"wildly f*cking inaccurate"

From an end-user perspective, it makes it look like data such as
flavor access settings get lost between edits (because the API pulls
the access list from the wrong flavor)

Letting the API assign a new flavorid on changes.  The comments
around this handler code imply that is the desired behaviour, anyhow.

Change-Id: I5403202396a7b136b0ae8637d6aae1cf32550747
Closes-Bug: #1276371

commit_message:
Don't copy the flavorid when updating flavors

The Nova API makes the implicit assumption that flavorids are unique,
so if one creates two flavors with the same flavorid, subsequent
requests for flavor information can vary between "inaccurate" and
"wildly f*cking inaccurate"

From an end-user perspective, it makes it look like data such as
flavor access settings get lost between edits (because the API pulls
the access list from the wrong flavor)

Let the API assign a new flavorid on changes.  The comments around
the handler code imply that is the desired behaviour, anyhow.

Change-Id: I5403202396a7b136b0ae8637d6aae1cf32550747
Closes-Bug: 1276371

commit_message:
Add scenario test for load balancer

This test checks basic load balancing.

The following is the scenario outline:
  1. Create an instance
  2. SSH to the instance and start two servers
  3. Create a load balancer
  4. Send 10 requests to a floating ip associated with a VIP
     and check that they are shared between the two servers
     and that both of them get equal portions of the requests

bp lbaas-scenario-tests

Change-Id: Ia864a6f532ea58747f04658eb38535ee06a303cb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/97/58697/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix os-svc-restart to exit correctly without -n.

Similar to os-svc-enable, it was trying to run when invoked
incorrectly.

Change-Id: Ice285d3796149f0c82521da7c5112375cf15c1fe
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/56/71156/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: exit $1 h) usage 0;; \?) usage 0;; :) usage 1;; usage 1
deleted_lines: h) usage; exit 0;; \?) usage; exit 1;; :) usage; exit 1;; usage

commit_message:
Configure floating IPs addresses after NAT rules

Change the behaviour of the L3 agent in order to set the IP addresses
for the floating IPs on the external gateway interface after the
relevant NAT rules have been applied.
This will avoid a transitory period in which the floating IP exists
and is reachable but it not yet wired to the actual target.

Partial-Bug: #1265505

Change-Id: Ib382fde021868bab2185f2fa5bdee86559148ba7

commit_message:
The rescue tests requires neutron resources

test_rescued_vm_add_remove_security_group and
the test_rescued_vm_associate_dissociate_floating_ip does not makes
sense if the instance does not have a network connection.

'network' and 'subnet' would be sufficient for the security_group test
case, but the router is required for floating_ip test case.

Closes-Bug: #1274121
Change-Id: Ic8e70d5e549573213b2930d88b5d7da5cd4cf855
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/75/71575/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Speed up unit tests without coverage

Previously coverage command is always used even if coverage is
not enabled and this makes unit tests slower.

Change-Id: I4311164ef907fbdc66ac66d4999b25054bc9eebd
Closes-Bug: #1272979

commit_message:
Support not-json error responses

When an error response body isn't a valid json, the content is used as
string.

Change-Id: Id5c9e55e397c1a9f3516090343c1948c87e60ac9
Closes-Bug: #1276638

deleted_lines: body = _("ERROR: {0}").format(body.get('error_message', body))

While there is support to cpu shares (cpu_weight)

compute_unit_per_vcpu in Flavor's extra_spec,
track the used compute_units in Host Manager
and resource tracker and compare them to the
host's compute_units capacity.

The compute node is assigned with compute_units (e.g. 1000),

Change-Id: I985a7e6ec5c2d53f821e383f92eeeb9fa30a3771

commit_message:
WIP:Add CPU entitlement support in resource model

While there is support to cpu shares (cpu_weight)
at the driver level, it is not yet modeled
and enforced by the scheduler. This WIP adds
compute_unit_per_vcpu in Flavor's extra_spec,
track the used compute_units in Host Manager
and resource tracker and compare them to the
host's compute_units capacity.

The compute node is assigned with compute_units (e.g. 1000),
Flavor is assigned with compute_unit_per_vcpu (e.g. 250, 500, 1000)

implements: blueprint cpu-entitlement (WIP)

DocImpact

Change-Id: I985a7e6ec5c2d53f821e383f92eeeb9fa30a3771

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from sqlalchemy import Column, Integer from nova.db.sqlalchemy import api as db from nova.db.sqlalchemy import types from nova.db.sqlalchemy import utils def upgrade(migrate_engine): compute_nodes = utils.get_table(migrate_engine, 'compute_nodes') compute_units = Column('compute_units', Integer, nullable=True) compute_units_used = Column('compute_units_used', Integer, nullable=True) compute_nodes.create_column(compute_units) compute_nodes.create_column(compute_units_used) shadow_compute_nodes = utils.get_table(migrate_engine, db._SHADOW_TABLE_PREFIX + 'compute_nodes') compute_units = Column('compute_units', Integer, nullable=True) compute_units_used = Column('compute_units_used', Integer, nullable=True) shadow_compute_nodes.create_column(compute_units) shadow_compute_nodes.create_column(compute_units_used) # NOTE: don't need to populate the new columns since they will # automatically be populate by a periodic task def downgrade(migrate_engine): compute_nodes = utils.get_table(migrate_engine, 'compute_nodes') compute_nodes.drop_column('compute_units') compute_nodes.drop_column('compute_units_used') shadow_compute_nodes = utils.get_table(migrate_engine, db._SHADOW_TABLE_PREFIX + 'compute_nodes') shadow_compute_nodes.drop_column('compute_units') shadow_compute_nodes.drop_column('compute_units_used')

commit_message:
Remove vi modelines

We don't need to have the vi modelines in each source file,
it can be set in a user's vimrc if required.
Also a check is added to hacking to detect if they are re-added.

Change-Id: Iaeb9352461165fc19f31177d47a9211b21ed1125
Closes-Bug: #1229324

commit_message:
Remove vi modelines

We don't need to have the vi modelines in each source file,
it can be set in a user's vimrc if required.
Also a check is added to hacking to detect if they are re-added.

Change-Id: I903d09557f804c08179bf24bf25295004ad96ca9
Closes-Bug: #1229324
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/17/71717/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Restrict flavor fields input on creation/update.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-16 14:46:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/35ab9c5fd506f3ab1d30772d42488bb9c27eba9e', 'message': 'Restrict VCPU & Ram input on flavor creation/edit.

If ram or vcpu is set to <= 0, an update message error
is shown, but the flavor get deleted.
The reason is that update flavor is not yet supported so horizon
will delete the flavor and create a new one, failing in the last case.

Fields ram and vcpus need to be >= 1 to create a flavor.

Change-Id: I20d178bad6e4e50c0963acdec72ebedb9bbaba17
Closes-Bug: #1269638
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-01-16 17:28:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/a802f11c3bc85174deb140b88e10009b940fa579', 'message': 'Restrict flavor fields input on creation/update.

If flavor properties are invalid, an update message error
is shown, but the flavor get deleted.
The reason is that update flavor is not yet supported so horizon
will delete the flavor and create a new one, failing in the last case.

Fields ram and vcpus need to be >= 1 and eph_gb, swap_mb and disk_gb
>= 0 to create a flavor.

Change-Id: I20d178bad6e4e50c0963acdec72ebedb9bbaba17
Closes-Bug: #1269638
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2014-01-17 13:38:28.000000000', 'files': ['openstack_dashboard/dashboards/admin/flavors/workflows.py', 'openstack_dashboard/dashboards/admin/flavors/tests.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/7fb3afaf3cb70de436b00f6a8d80fad99c628767', 'message': 'Restrict flavor fields input on creation/update.

is shown, but the flavor get deleted.
The reason is that update flavor is not yet supported so horizon
will delete the flavor and create a new one, failing in the last case.

Fields ram and vcpus need to be >= 1 and eph_gb, swap_mb and disk_gb
>= 0 to create a flavor.

Change-Id: I20d178bad6e4e50c0963acdec72ebedb9bbaba17
Closes-Bug: #1269638
'}]
commit_message:
Restrict flavor fields input on creation/update.

If flavor properties are invalid, an update message error
is shown, but the flavor get deleted.
The reason is that update flavor is not yet supported so horizon
will delete the flavor and create a new one, failing in the last case.

Fields ram and vcpus need to be >= 1 and eph_gb, swap_mb and disk_gb
>= 0 to create a flavor.

Change-Id: I20d178bad6e4e50c0963acdec72ebedb9bbaba17
Closes-Bug: #1269638

added_lines: @test.create_stubs({api.keystone: ('tenant_list',), api.nova: ('flavor_get', 'flavor_list',)}) def test_update_flavor_invalid_vcpu_mem_fails(self): flavor = self.flavors.first() projects = self.tenants.list() eph = getattr(flavor, 'OS-FLV-EXT-DATA:ephemeral') api.nova.flavor_get(IsA(http.HttpRequest), flavor.id) \ .MultipleTimes().AndReturn(flavor) api.keystone.tenant_list(IsA(http.HttpRequest)) \ .MultipleTimes().AndReturn([projects, False]) api.nova.flavor_list(IsA(http.HttpRequest), None) \ .AndReturn(self.flavors.list()) self.mox.ReplayAll() # run get test url = reverse('horizon:admin:flavors:update', args=[flavor.id]) resp = self.client.get(url) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 200) self.assertTemplateUsed(resp, "admin/flavors/update.html") # run post test workflow_data = {'flavor_id': flavor.id, 'name': flavor.name, 'vcpus': 0, 'memory_mb': 0, 'disk_gb': flavor.disk, 'swap_mb': flavor.swap, 'eph_gb': eph, 'is_public': True} resp = self.client.post(url, workflow_data) self.assertFormErrors(resp, 2, 'Ensure this value is greater than or ' 'equal to 1.')

commit_message:
Add a Deploymet and a Task in REST API

Controllers for a Task and a Deployment provide CRUD operations. A full
list of supported endpoints and method of v1 (all paths have got
a prefix /v1):

GET     /deployments
POST    /deployments
GET     /deployments/{deploy_id}
DELETE  /deployments/{deploy_id}
POST    /deployments/{deploy_id}/recreate
GET     /deployments/engines
GET     /deployments/providers

GET     /tasks
POST    /tasks
GET     /tasks/{task_id}
DELETE  /task/{task_id}?force=true
GET     /task/{task_id}/results

Also, rally.objects.{Task,Deployment} support iterations, 'get_all'
method that returns a list of objects. A Task have got a 'get_results'
method. Some orchestration API methods return an objects as a result.

TODO: A proper exception handling.

blueprint rally-service-api-v1

Change-Id: Ied632fd21aae305a0f1f67dea7a4401f9652bf9e

commit_message:
Add an os-compute-network role

Now that we have broken nova-network from inclusion in the
openstack-compute::compute recipe, add a new role for nova-network to
the openstack-chef-repo.

Change-Id: I534957db44ebbd4fa04421990dda92303d2de7d5

commit_message:
Implement grizzly to havana upgrade for network

Uninstall quantum packages, stop quantum service based
on attributes defined. Need to remove the dashboard conf file
if an all-in-one install because the dashboard packages
are removed automatically.

Change-Id: I40b343322f782420ebfd016bd9bd67248dc20e79
Implements: openstack-upgrade

commit_message:
VMware: Update block_device_info in test_spawn_attach_volume_vmdk

We can avoid mocking block_device_info_get_mapping if we pass
block_device_mapping to spawn as part of block_device_info.

This change also moves 'mount_device' to block_device_mapping from
block_device_info, adds 'root_device_name' to block_device_info, and
prepends /dev/ to both of these paths. All of these changes reflect
how the data is actually passed in.

Change-Id: I17ff3cc2fdf231206834c34cadeee870cc69a1ee

deleted_lines: root_disk = [{'connection_info': connection_info}] v_driver, 'block_device_info_get_mapping', autospec=True ) as mock_block_device_info_get_mapping, \ mock.patch.object( mock_block_device_info_get_mapping.return_value = root_disk block_device_info = {'mount_device': 'vda'}

commit_message:
(WIP) Resource Event co-relatation

Adding a relationship between events and resources,
Specifying the resource for each an event has been raised.

Partially implements bp specify-event-api

Change-Id: I7d2e9d5065394e171b701916b4250fc68a496b0f

added_lines: # -*- encoding: utf-8 -*- # # Author: John Tran <jhtran@att.com> # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from sqlalchemy import Column from sqlalchemy import DateTime from sqlalchemy import Index from sqlalchemy import Integer from sqlalchemy import MetaData from sqlalchemy import String from sqlalchemy import Table from sqlalchemy import UniqueConstraint from sqlalchemy import ForeignKey def upgrade(migrate_engine): meta = MetaData(bind=migrate_engine) resource = Table('resource', meta, autoload=True) event = Table('event', meta, autoload=True) res_event = Table( 'resource_event_assoc', meta, Column('resource_id', String(255), ForeignKey('resource.id'), primary_key=True), Column('event_id', Integer, ForeignKey('event.id'), primary_key=True), mysql_engine='InnoDB', mysql_charset='utf8', ) trait = Table('trait', meta, autoload=True) trait.c.t_string.alter(type=String) tables = [res_event] for i in sorted(tables): i.create() def downgrade(migrate_engine): meta = MetaData(bind=migrate_engine) trait = Table('trait', meta, autoload=True) trait.c.t_string.alter(type=String(255)) for name in ['resource_event_assoc']: t = Table(name, meta, autoload=True) t.drop()

commit_message:
Remove security_group related quota from v3 API

Remove 'security_group_rules' and 'security_groups' from usages
for v3 API, that should be access to neutron directly.
Get 'key_pair' usage for user and remove it for project since
it is user basis resource.

Change-Id: I3eb83eeb950f3b1b4696113ecce88f5b35fdc022
Closes-bug: #1240361
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/60/58760/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: result = dict() for k, v in values.items(): # Remove 'security_group_rules' and 'key_pairs' from usages for # a project since we can not get the usage. if ((k == 'security_group_rules') or (not user_id and k == 'key_pairs')): continue # Get 'key_pairs' usage for a user. if user_id and k == 'key_pairs': v['in_use'] = db.key_pair_count_by_user(context, user_id) result[k] = v return result
deleted_lines: return values

subject: Corrects host-validation for mysql-user
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-17 20:28:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/20101529f308cdfafaf721271973aa0e04a298e1', 'message': 'Corrects host-validation for mysql-user

Reasons:
- The validation applied in _is_valid_host_name are:
  1. Return True, if name is none or it is '%', else,
  2. Check some other tests, if CONF.hostname_require_ipv4,
     where it checks for host is in an IP format.
- Problem is if hostname_require_ipv4 is True and host-name had
  some a string with '%' like '%.com' it would fail the validation.

Changes:
- Changes the host-validation condition to check that if % is in the
  hostname, which makes the host to be valid, for eg. '%.com', and
  'abc.%.com" both are valid.

commit_message:
Corrects host-validation for mysql-user

Reasons:
- The validation applied in _is_valid_host_name are:
  1. If host-name is None or it is '%'.
  2. Test for a valid IP with for if CONF.hostname_require_ipv4,
- Problem is, if a non-ip based host-name had a string with '%'
  like '%.com' it would fail the validation.
- While putting the condition to check '%' in host-name, there is still
  a need to eliminate consecutive % in name.

Changes:
- Changes the host-validation for non-ip hostname.
- Changes the host-name condition to check that if hostname has '%',
  but not consecutively to stop invalid entries like 'a%%.com'.

Change-Id: I249e4c23296df9c16dc23e0c5573c749c7ba10d7
Closes-Bug: #1199197

deleted_lines: if value in [None, "%"]:

commit_message:
Mark task as running before performing action.

Marking the task as running before calling the run method on the action makes sure that the task status is set running while a synchronous action executes.

Change-Id: Ida74384ac5cc910bd4e66ebf8591ed2599150304
Closes-Bug: #1274384
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/64/70064/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
WIP: cache compute_node_get_all in scheduler host_manager

This is a first draft, just to show the idea.

We already have the concept that the DB isn't the exact state of the world,
right now it's updated every 10 seconds. And we use the scheduler retry
mechanism to handle cases where the scheduler was wrong. This patch
extends the idea that the scheduler may have an outdated state of the
world and caches DB calls for a configurable mount of time.

This helps reduce the number of DB calls made by the scheduler at the
cost of scheduler accuracy. To maintain backwards compatibility caching
will be turned off by default.

Note: oslo's memorycache  module was changed because if the cache is very
large iterating over all keys can take a while. This will be broken out into separate patch.

Change-Id: I76dc193020a9316d4e4c3580ed9815e83f4411bf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/53/57053/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.openstack.common import memorycache MC = None def _get_cached_compute_node_get_all(self, context): global MC cache_key = "host_manager_compuite_node_get_all" if MC is None: MC = memorycache.get_client() compute_nodes = MC.get(cache_key) if not compute_nodes: compute_nodes = db.compute_node_get_all(context) MC.set(cache_key, compute_nodes, 60) #TODO(jogo): make this two config options. cache by number of seconds and number of calls return compute_nodes compute_nodes = self._get_cached_compute_node_get_all(context)
deleted_lines: compute_nodes = db.compute_node_get_all(context)

commit_message:
Add trusts to Solum

This patch adds keystone trusts to Solum.
Trusts can be used to call API methods
of OpenStack services without user's
authentication token.

Change-Id: Ic6b566fb116c38f908e11441d1f3dd054fa84828
Implements: blueprint auth-trusts
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/solum refs/changes/38/66738/20 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # # Copyright 2014 - Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. from keystoneclient.v3 import client as keystone_client from oslo.config import cfg CONF = cfg.CONF def client(requestContext): '''This function returns a keystone client authenticated in Keystone. It is expected that auth_token contains correct value as it was a part of request validated by a keystone middleware''' auth_url = CONF.keystone_authtoken.auth_uri keystone = keystone_client.Client(username=requestContext['user_name'], token=requestContext['auth_token'], tenant_id=requestContext['project_id'], auth_url=auth_url) keystone.management_url = auth_url return keystone def client_for_trusts(username, password, project_name=None, trust_id=None, project_id=None): '''This is a keystone client which should be authenticated by established trust''' auth_url = CONF.keystone_authtoken.auth_uri keystone = keystone_client.Client(username=username, password=password, tenant_name=project_name, tenant_id=project_id, auth_url=auth_url, trust_id=trust_id) keystone.management_url = auth_url return keystone def create_trust(requestContext): # k_client is a keystone client authenticated as user k_client = client() admin_user = CONF.keystone_authtoken.admin_user admin_password = CONF.keystone_authtoken.admin_password admin_tenant_name = CONF.keystone_authtoken.admin_tenant_name trustee_id = client_for_trusts( admin_user, admin_password, project_name=admin_tenant_name).user_id trust = k_client.trusts.create(trustor_user=client.user_id, trustee_user=trustee_id, impersonation=True, role_names=requestContext.get_pub('roles'), project=requestContext.get_pub('project_id') ) requestContext.set_priv(trust_id=trust.id) return trust.id def delete_trust(requestContext): if requestContext.trust_id: return admin_user = CONF.keystone_authtoken.admin_user admin_password = CONF.keystone_authtoken.admin_password keystone_client = client_for_trusts( admin_user, admin_password, requestContext.get_priv('trust_id')) keystone_client.trusts.delete(requestContext.get_priv('trust_id'))

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-05 22:40:16.000000000', 'files': ['openstack_dashboard/dashboards/admin/projects/tables.py', 'openstack_dashboard/dashboards/admin/projects/workflows.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/ff82969f4c3c501f68953bf3659c1c2e05d075f6', 'message': "Restrict the length of the project name input

current code, it doesn't check or restrict that from UI side, i.e. user
will be able to type in more than what is allowed. After form
submission, it will fail but there is no clear message telling user what

After adding the code to restrict the max length of the project name

Closes-Bug: #1276389

commit_message:
Restrict the length of the project name input

There is an allowed maximum length for project name field, but in
current code, it doesn't check or restrict that from UI side, i.e. user
will be able to type in more than what is allowed. After form
submission, it will fail but there is no clear message telling user what
caused failure.

After adding the code to restrict the max length of the project name
field, user will not be able to input more than what is allowed, thus
this error will be prevented from UI.

Change-Id: I6e61387c1e89e47e16354719870047c6e4760989
Closes-Bug: #1276389

commit_message:
Remove default_notification_level from conf

This config option is used when you use the notify_wrapper wrapper
function from openstack.common. As we don't use the wrapper we don't
ever require the config option so we shouldn't show it to users.

blueprint oslo-messaging

Change-Id: I95280af37a84c71131fb2fc92c9302b8926c95bd

commit_message:
Depending on python-swiftclient>=1.6

Now we're depending on python-swiftclient>=1.6 since the parameter
'headers' was introduced since python-swiftclient 1.6. This is a
regression issue introduced by patch:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/48913/

get_object(container, obj, resp_chunk_size=None, query_string=None,
response_dict=None, headers=None)

Closes-Bug: #1276033

Change-Id: I174f2dc53a402d48301b17839be8b5fa97064805

commit_message:
Expose image property 'owner' in v2 API

The 'owner' property on an image is exposed in v1 but does
not appear in the v2 image response. It would be useful to
have this available.

docImpact
Implement blueprint expose-owner-in-v2

Change-Id: I90f68d57e185f4a5ee63cd97bd5597948dde33ea

commit_message:
Handle API 500 response in OS::Nova::Server

novaclient raises a ClientException when a 500 response code is returned
from the Nova API.  Previously, this would cause the stack action to
fail.  Log a warning instead.

Closes-Bug: #1276517
Change-Id: I8f00d476c8d7166aca74fdcd3e0f2621c00d9802
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/44/71644/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from heat.engine import clients def test_server_create_500_error(self): return_server = self.fc.servers.list()[0] server = self._setup_test_server(return_server, 'test_create_500') server.resource_id = 1234 check_iterations = [0] # Bind fake get method which Server.check_create_complete will call def activate_status(server): check_iterations[0] += 1 if check_iterations[0] == 1: server.status = 'BUILD' elif check_iterations[0] == 2: msg = ("ClientException: The server has either erred or is " "incapable of performing the requested operation.") raise clients.novaclient.exceptions.ClientException(500, msg) elif check_iterations[0] > 2: server.status = 'ACTIVE' return_server.get = activate_status.__get__(return_server) self.m.ReplayAll() scheduler.TaskRunner(server.create)() self.assertEqual('CREATE', server.action) self.assertEqual('COMPLETE', server.status) self.m.VerifyAll() def test_server_suspend_500_error(self): return_server = self.fc.servers.list()[1] server = self._create_test_server(return_server, 'test_suspend_500') server.resource_id = 1234 # Override the get_servers_1234 handler d1 = {'server': self.fc.client.get_servers_detail()[1]['servers'][0]} d2 = copy.deepcopy(d1) d1['server']['status'] = 'ACTIVE' d2['server']['status'] = 'SUSPENDED' self.m.StubOutWithMock(self.fc.client, 'get_servers_1234') get = self.fc.client.get_servers_1234 get().AndReturn((200, d1)) get().AndReturn((200, d1)) msg = ("ClientException: The server has either erred or is " "incapable of performing the requested operation.") get().AndRaise(clients.novaclient.exceptions.ClientException(500, msg)) get().AndReturn((200, d2)) self.m.ReplayAll() scheduler.TaskRunner(server.suspend)() self.assertEqual('SUSPEND', server.action) self.assertEqual('COMPLETE', server.status) self.m.VerifyAll()

subject: Adds tcp_keepalive and tcp_keepidle config options
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-13 16:35:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/a556de0eeb760329411e84430f1a6f17fd1e6744', 'message': "Adds tcp_keepalive and tcp_keepidle config options

Currently the wsgi server will not close connections once requests
complete and will not enable keepalive on it's wsgi sockets. This can
be a problem for those who need to align the server keepalive with
load balancer timeouts without modifying system keepalive settings.

To rememdy this we add new config options tcp_keepalive and
tcp_keepidle which are disabled by default to remain backwards
compatible.

Closes-bug: bug 1260406
Co-authored-by: Hirofumi Ichihara <ichihara.hirofumi@lab.ntt.co.jp>
Change-Id: Ic53402c57e1ebe44cde4c18e5e15200dcbbcb04b

commit_message:
Adds tcp_keepalive and tcp_keepidle config options

Currently the wsgi server will not close connections once requests
complete and will not enable keepalive on it's wsgi sockets. This can
be a problem for those who need to align the server keepalive with
load balancer timeouts without modifying system keepalive settings.

To remedy this we add new config options tcp_keepalive and
tcp_keepidle which are disabled by default to remain backwards
compatible.

DocImpact: "new config options for wsgi tcp_keepalive & tcp_keepidle"
Closes-bug: bug 1260406
Co-authored-by: Hirofumi Ichihara <ichihara.hirofumi@lab.ntt.co.jp>
Change-Id: Ic53402c57e1ebe44cde4c18e5e15200dcbbcb04b

added_lines: def __init__(self, application, host=None, port=None, threads=1000, keepalive=False, keepidle=None): self.keepalive = keepalive self.keepidle = keepidle # Optionally enable keepalive on the wsgi socket. if self.keepalive: _socket.setsockopt(socket.SOL_SOCKET, socket.SO_KEEPALIVE, 1) # This option isn't available in the OS X version of eventlet if hasattr(socket, 'TCP_KEEPIDLE') and self.keepidle is not None: _socket.setsockopt(socket.IPPROTO_TCP, socket.TCP_KEEPIDLE, self.keepidle)

Provides the framework for creating authentication plugins and using
them from a session object.

To allow this system to co-exist with the original client there is a bit
of a hack. The client object itself is now also an authentication
plugin, that supports the original client pattern. If a client is
created without a session object then that session object uses the
client as it's authentication plugin.

What this means is that when calling client.authenticate we hand off to
the session.authenticate function to authenticate the session object.
In the original case this will then call back into the client and
authentication will proceed as normal.

If someone calls client.authenticate and there is another plugin in it's
place then the client will take the auth_ref from that plugin and
attempt to fill the client variables in for compatibility.

Similarly if the session prompts a re-authenticate then it will call
back to the client to update it's token and maintain compatibility.

Change-Id: I682c8dcd3705148aaa804a91f4ed48a5b74bdc12
blueprint: auth-plugins

commit_message:
Create Authentication Plugins

Provides the framework for creating authentication plugins and using
them from a session object.

To allow this system to co-exist with the original client there is a bit
of a hack. The client object itself is now also an authentication
plugin, that supports the original client pattern. If a client is
created without a session object then that session object uses the
client as it's authentication plugin.

Change-Id: I682c8dcd3705148aaa804a91f4ed48a5b74bdc12
blueprint: auth-plugins

added_lines: def _authenticatable(f): @functools.wraps(f) def wrapper(self, *args, **kwargs): reauth = kwargs.pop('reauth', True) try: return f(self, *args, **kwargs) except exceptions.AuthPluginUnauthenticated: if reauth: self.do_authenticate() try: return f(self, *args, **kwargs) except exceptions.AuthPluginUnauthenticated: return None else: raise return wrapper def __init__(self, auth=None, session=None, original_ip=None, verify=True, cert=None, timeout=None, debug=False, user_agent=None, redirect=2, reauth=True): self.auth = auth self.reauth = reauth @_authenticatable def _get_token(self): return self.auth.get_token() logger=None, user_agent=None, authenticated=None, reauth=None, **kwargs): :param bool authenticated: True if a token should be attached to this request, False if not or None for attach if an auth_plugin is available. (optional, defaults to None) if authenticated is None: authenticated = self.auth is not None if reauth is None: reauth = self.reauth if authenticated: if not self.auth: raise exceptions.MissingAuthPlugin("Token Required") token = self._get_token(reauth=reauth) if not token: raise exceptions.AuthorizationFailure("No token Available") headers['X-Auth-Token'] = token def do_authenticate(self, **kwargs): if not self.auth: raise exceptions.MissingAuthPlugin("No plugin to authenticate") kwargs['session'] = self return self.auth.do_authenticate(**kwargs)

commit_message:
Provide a conversion function for creating session

Session.construct will create a session based upon the kwargs that used
to be passed to a client __init__ function. This will allow clients an
easy path to providing compatibility with deprecated arguments.

Make use of the function throughout discovery. Discovery was initially
released prior to the session object being completed and was therefore
handled with the same arguments as a client. Instead we should use a
session object so use the conversion function to convert those kwargs
into a session object if one is not provided.

Change-Id: I8dc1e0810ea6ebc6ea648ec37d7881825c566676

commit_message:
Resource for querying available language packs

We want the ability to specify the language pack that should be used
to build a DU. For this, we need the ability to query the language
packs that are currently available. Defined a resource to query
available language packs. The resource is defined at
(/v1/language_packs).

This code is based on the new API worker architecture

Partly implements: blueprint specify-lang-pack

Change-Id: I32fbfe2388f1e571d8ddcce001b6752d08747e1e

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from solum.api.controllers.v1.datamodel import language_pack from solum.api.handlers import handler class LanguagePackHandler(handler.Handler): """Fulfills a request on the language pack resource.""" def __init__(self): pass def get(self, id): response = language_pack.LanguagePack.sample() return response

commit_message:
Don't try to restore VM's in state ERROR.

We don't try to restore VM's that are in a failed BUILDING state, so
attempting to start ERROR VMs is more than a little weird. The one
exception to this rule are VMs that are in RESIZE_MIGRATING, since
recovery is already attempted. It's also a problem, because many ERROR
states aren't recoverable from (at the moment anyhow).

Closes-Bug: #1272623
Change-Id: I0599b83a82ad3ee67a92126d3b57df5b02e20539
Co-Authored-By: Robert Collins <rbtcollins@hp.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/08/69108/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if (instance.vm_state == vm_states.ERROR): LOG.debug(_("Instance is in ERROR state."), instance=instance) return

commit_message:
Add tests for swift-ring-builder

Add some tests for essential methods in swift-ring-builder.
Tests for removing or changing device settings are executed
with different search values to cover many possible command
line arguments.

Currently tested methods:

- create ring
- add device
- remove device
- set weight
- set info
- set min_part_hours
- set replicas

Tests use swift.common.ring.RingBuilder to verify actions.

Catching and testing output from print statements is not
tested, because this requires redirecting sys.stdout during
tests and that might have some sideeffects for testing tools.

bin/swift-ring-builder has been moved to swift/cli/ringbuilder.py
and slightly modified to work as before (mainly due to no more
existing global variables since that part of the code has been
moved inside a main() function).

Change-Id: Ia63f59a8faca1fad990784f27532ca07a2125454
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/06/71106/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: swift-ring-builder = swift.cli.ringbuilder:main
deleted_lines: bin/swift-ring-builder

commit_message:
Reorganize docker-plugin for consistency

Package and Module names shouldn't have dashes in them, since it makes
it harder to import them (i.e. one cannot use ``import dashed-module``).

Also, moving docker resource under resources for consistency.

Partial-Bug: #1271226
Change-Id: I785b626a99516ebe6444296cf62a78dd96355060

commit_message:
Restructure Rackspace resources

During doc generation, resources have their own templates and need
to be separate from non-resource modules.  This removes the ``heat``
``engine`` and ``plugins`` folders and moves all resources into a
``resources`` folder, effectively separating the custom Rackspace
Client from custom Rackspace resources.

Partial-Bug: #1271226
Change-Id: Idbdc8400d30e2e745a2dc1b2d2fa1b7cff50d57b

commit_message:
Don't use shred for volume_clear=zero

We should just call copy_volume unless volume_clear='shred' is
specified.

Change-Id: Id5e15b000cf0d6146ec13f42ff5bb611b6f18484
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/70/71070/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_clear_volume_zero(self): self.mox.StubOutWithMock(volume_utils, 'copy_volume') volume_utils.copy_volume("/dev/zero", "volume_path", 1, CONF.volume_dd_blocksize, sync=True, execute=utils.execute)
deleted_lines: def test_clear_volume_zero_and_shred(self): clear_cmd = ['shred', '-n0', '-z', '-s1MiB', "volume_path"] self.mox.StubOutWithMock(utils, "execute") utils.execute(*clear_cmd, run_as_root=True)

commit_message:
Replace Policy Index with Policy Name in Response Headers

The policy index is intended for internal use only so response
headers should always use the name, not the index.

Change-Id: I9395e99994fd412d40877340419f90b08b911dd4
Implements: blueprint storage-policies

commit_message:
heat_keystoneclient add support for stack domain projects

Adds support for creating projects inside the heat stack domain.

A new project will be created in the stack domain if the stack creates
any InstanceUser resource, and the "stack domain project" will then
encapsulate all users associated with resources in the stack.

Adds a new stack_user_domain option which will be used to specify the
name of the domain where heat will create the projects/users.

Change-Id: I7bb1830489baf5fb6761d7e1c914dc3ab0450181
blueprint: instance-users

commit_message:
Add time_type dictionary to test_migrations

A number of postgresql migration tests fail because the test case
is verifying that an sqlalchemy.types.DATETIME column was created.
When the column type is checked, however, postgresql reports the type as
sqlalchemy.types.TIMESTAMP.  The mismatch causes numerous
test cases to fail for postgresql.

This creates a dictionary for each engine being tested to handle the
different time types.

Change-Id: Ic9921ff9fda001a66c0ea3a6a75c8adefa60b107
Closes-bug: 1262426

commit_message:
Empty file shouldn't contain copyright nor license

According to policy change in HACKING:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#openstack-licensing
empty files should no longer contain copyright notices.

Change-Id: If51c1fe7b28c1b9976429fcbea28bd4953dd41bf
Closes-Bug: #1262424

commit_message:
Replace non-ascii symbols in docs

In order to successfully run sphinxcontrib-spelling on Ceilometer docs we need
to replace all non-ascii symbols with the analogous ones from ascii.

Without this fix sphinxcontrib-spelling will fail with:
"UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\u2019'
in position 8: ordinal not in range(128)"

Change-Id: I37891b9471571c3509aece3949d9593738f99849

commit_message:
Hyper-V: Change variable in debug log message

The variable used in the log message is incorrect. The log message
outputs the file size instead of the internal VHD size.

Closes-bug #1275805

Change-Id: I270709098e058cf51bbe6494b903a461b3938d15

commit_message:
Add tests for handlers

Handlers should be tested independently of controllers. I added
tests for current handlers.

Controller tests should mock the 'handler' part and test
controller code only. I have not modified any controller tests
due to the many pending patchs on the db that changes tests, in
order to avoid conflicts.

However, I will create a bug not to forget to improve controller
later

Change-Id: I0080c9456fd39af75bcac7642e1a225189bef59b

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from solum.api.handlers import operation_handler as operation from solum.tests import base class TestOperationHandler(base.BaseTestCase): def test_operation_get(self): handler = operation.OperationHandler() res = handler.get('test_id') self.assertIsNotNone(res) def test_operation_get_all(self): handler = operation.OperationHandler() res = handler.get_all() self.assertIsNotNone(res)

commit_message:
Removes cmd_rd_client in scripts/redstack

Reasons:
- The ancient mode of retrieving token is no more a fashion.
- Trove client which gives direct access to trove commands,
- More help for accessing troveclient is at,
https://github.com/openstack/python-troveclient/blob/master/README.rst

Change-Id: Ia46c9a46e09ffbccac1a9f3e62ce311682736f03
Closes-Bug: #1272183

commit_message:
Quick fix for TypeError on FakePecanRequest

Some patches currently in review have the following error
TypeError: 'FakePecanRequest' object does not support item assignment
The error happens when we try to set a custom content-type
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/70168/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/69855/

It can potentially break other coming patches

I fixed this bug in another review https://review.openstack.org/#/c/70975/
but it should not be in branches with dependent patches and get in master
the earliest.

Change-Id: I74aa9edb264c7ce8990752796d69e5faef30accb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/solum refs/changes/78/71678/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __setitem__(self, index, value): setattr(self, index, value)

commit_message:
adding configuration group support

This allows users to make custom configurations groups and apply them to
multiple instances. Configuration parameters that can be set are listed
in the validation_rules.json file.

implements blueprint configuration-management

Change-Id: I99b0bfe51c131ace30774e75e30d620101ed2e0b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/68/53168/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright 2013 Rackspace # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from trove.openstack.common import log as logging LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class ConfigurationView(object): def __init__(self, configuration): self.configuration = configuration def data(self): configuration_dict = { "id": self.configuration.id, "name": self.configuration.name, "description": self.configuration.description } return {"configuration": configuration_dict} class ConfigurationsView(object): def __init__(self, configurations): self.configurations = configurations def data(self): data = [] for configuration in self.configurations: data.append(self.data_for_configuration(configuration)) return {"configurations": data} def data_for_configuration(self, configuration): view = ConfigurationView(configuration) return view.data()['configuration'] class DetailedConfigurationView(object): def __init__(self, configuration): self.configuration = configuration def instances(self): instances_list = [] for instance in self.configuration.instances: LOG.debug("creating view: %r" % instance) instances_list.append( { "id": instance.id, "name": instance.name } ) return instances_list def instances_data(self): instances_list = self.instances() return {"instances": instances_list} def data(self): values = {} for configItem in self.configuration.items: key = configItem.configuration_key value = configItem.configuration_value values[key] = value instances_dict = self.instances() configuration_dict = \ { "id": self.configuration.id, "name": self.configuration.name, "description": self.configuration.description, "values": values, "instances": instances_dict, } return {"configuration": configuration_dict} class ConfigurationParametersView(object): def __init__(self, configurationParameters): self.configurationParameters = configurationParameters def data(self): return self.configurationParameters

commit_message:
Support Neutron security groups in scenario testing

The methods
NetworkScenarioTest._create_security_group()
and
NetworkScenarioTest.create_loginable_secgroup_rule()
use the nova client by default.

Added helper functions "*_neutron" that use the neutron (network)
client.
Moved old implementation into "*_nova" for old usage.

Adds methods to scenario/manager to allow for generic creation of
neutron secgroup and rules as existing methods only create a secgroup
with login rules (incoming ping and ssh).

Partial-Bug: #1277040
Change-Id: I6de4bf9f7deed215cf61c87c3ae3f4240982523e
(cherry picked from commit eb69f3fc9e245e8a59845976861947c695bec314)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/61/71561/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self._create_loginable_secgroup_rule_nova()
deleted_lines: self.create_loginable_secgroup_rule()

commit_message:
Adds ping method to remote client

Allowing pinging via ssh host.
Pushing this because many new patches are using this (at least 3 of mine)

Partial-Bug: #1277040
Change-Id: I48931e968e76a24658bcda298e98f3a40c8358d1
(cherry picked from commit 5f670abe2ccbb850eda4d2a25748bd763f2815ae)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/62/71562/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Some components are reporting error status in lower case # so case sensitive comparisons can really mess things # up. if new_status.lower() == error_status.lower(): return proc.returncode == 0 def _ssh_to_server(self, server, private_key): ssh_login = self.config.compute.image_ssh_user return self.get_remote_client(server, username=ssh_login, private_key=private_key)
deleted_lines: if new_status == error_status: if proc.returncode == 0: return True

commit_message:
fix DeletableSubnet in api/network/common

DeletableSubnet._router_ids was defined as a static attribute, causing
errors on tearDown working with multiple {router,subnet} couples as it
tries to disconnect subnet from all routers existing instead of all
routers connected to it

Partial-Bug: #1277040
Change-Id: Id446d7bb2be117ea56b52e6a644b259089cdc158
(cherry picked from commit ca1d9a9523b9d6615a8db9f785144e22adb8c81b)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/63/71563/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super(DeletableSubnet, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) self._router_ids = set()
deleted_lines: _router_ids = set()

commit_message:
scenario cross_tenant_connectivity

test conectivity between VMs in the same tenant and on different
tenants.
for each case, test that default state blocks traffic(*), that security
rules allow only specified traffic

(*)negative connectivity check is skipped until bug 1252620 is fixed
   TODO(yfried): enable them once bug is fixed

Also adds workaround for bug 1247568 in python-neutronclient (preventing
tearDownClass from ignoring deleted neutron resources

Partial-Bug: #1277040
Change-Id: I212873d46e20ff3161e376105af18020b1cf1c9d
(cherry picked from commit 4d7efa6d030bca335c7fb9f45e53650ef2ceb562)

deleted_lines: from tempest.api.network import common as net_common def _get_router(self, tenant_id): """Retrieve a router for the given tenant id. If a public router has been configured, it will be returned. If a public router has not been configured, but a public network has, a tenant router will be created and returned that routes traffic to the public network. """ router_id = self.config.network.public_router_id network_id = self.config.network.public_network_id if router_id: result = self.network_client.show_router(router_id) return net_common.AttributeDict(**result['router']) elif network_id: router = self._create_router(tenant_id) router.add_gateway(network_id) return router else: raise Exception("Neither of 'public_router_id' or " "'public_network_id' has been defined.") def _create_router(self, tenant_id, namestart='router-smoke-'): name = rand_name(namestart) body = dict( router=dict( name=name, admin_state_up=True, tenant_id=tenant_id, ), ) result = self.network_client.create_router(body=body) router = net_common.DeletableRouter(client=self.network_client, **result['router']) self.assertEqual(router.name, name) self.set_resource(name, router) return router def _create_networks(self): network = self._create_network(self.tenant_id) router = self._get_router(self.tenant_id) subnet = self._create_subnet(network) subnet.add_to_router(router.id) self.networks.append(network) self.subnets.append(subnet) self.routers.append(router)

commit_message:
Fix log and test for NeutronAPI.update_port_dhcp_opts

The unit tets for NeutronAPI.update_port_dhcp_opts were raising the
wrong exception, and would pass regardless of the behaviour of
update_port_dhcp_opts.

This patch causes the mock to raise a neutron_client exception and
correctly asserts that ironic.common.neutron.NeutronAPI converts the
neutron client expcetion to an ironic exception.

It also adjusts the LOG behavior of this method to properly record
the exception traceback, which could be useful in determining the
failure in the neutron client.

Change-Id: I6f231b6a823386709b5778d140d6aa48ae4997ce

commit_message:
Make nova-compute-{kvm,qemu} packages overridable

To keep the "we define platform choices in the attributes" spirit, the
nova-compute "support packages" for ubuntu should be overridable, too.

This change makes them behave just like  to the
"#{db_type}_python_packages" in openstack-compute::nova-common.

Change-Id: Id38169121e52e0dc8be808c8822db55069e65e48

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-06 19:30:29.000000000', 'files': ['keystoneclient/common/cms.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient/commit/9dc231999b44a56f02a1c464110d17fa4c7d1bb6', 'message': 'Check for any monkeypatching

Checking oinly for monkeypatching of the ``os`` module is
insufficient.  A process might have chosen not to patch ``os`` but
still needs to use the eventlet version of Popen to deal with proper
forks.  This version checks if any modules have been monkeypatched
with the eventlet versions.

Closes-Bug: #1277231

Change-Id: Ia8d7150e9e7ced58132e8e90e7ad68fb3c7c3b9f
'}]
commit_message:
Check for any monkeypatching

Checking oinly for monkeypatching of the ``os`` module is
insufficient.  A process might have chosen not to patch ``os`` but
still needs to use the eventlet version of Popen to deal with proper
forks.  This version checks if any modules have been monkeypatched
with the eventlet versions.

Closes-Bug: #1277231

Change-Id: Ia8d7150e9e7ced58132e8e90e7ad68fb3c7c3b9f

commit_message:
Fix broken doc links on the index page

Commit 017f99120b1 did not move documentation from dev/ to developer/.
The links on the index page were updated incorrectly.
This change reverts that and fixes the broken links.

Change-Id: Ia2f3703589c469bfc2a5204bdd3becc4b09efd0d

commit_message:
On create_volume flow get rid of host parameter

On manager create_volume flow save host parameter to volume_ref immediately
when create volume_ref and remove host parameter from other tasks.

Change-Id: Ifc672741c317112b084a076ca65c11c5d0290930
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/52/70752/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __init__(self, db, host): self.host = host # NOTE(vish): so we don't have to get volume from db again before # passing it to the driver. volume_ref['host'] = self.host def __init__(self, db, event_suffix): host=volume_ref['host']) def __init__(self, db, driver): def __init__(self, db, event_suffix): super(CreateVolumeOnFinishTask, self).__init__(db, event_suffix) volume_flow.add(ExtractVolumeRefTask(db, host)) NotifyVolumeActionTask(db, "create.start"), CreateVolumeFromSpecTask(db, driver), CreateVolumeOnFinishTask(db, "create.end"))
deleted_lines: def __init__(self, db): def __init__(self, db, host, event_suffix): self.host = host host=self.host) def __init__(self, db, host, driver): self.host = host # NOTE(vish): so we don't have to get volume from db again before # passing it to the driver. volume_ref['host'] = self.host def __init__(self, db, host, event_suffix): super(CreateVolumeOnFinishTask, self).__init__(db, host, event_suffix) volume_flow.add(ExtractVolumeRefTask(db)) NotifyVolumeActionTask(db, host, "create.start"), CreateVolumeFromSpecTask(db, host, driver), CreateVolumeOnFinishTask(db, host, "create.end"))

commit_message:
adds support for configurations management

Reason:
Adding configuration group support for the python-troveclient

Changes:
adding configuration api calls
adding the compat client for tests and xml
added the shell cmds for the configurations in the client
made the path to datastore/version/parameters
added unit tests

partially implements blueprint configuration-management

Change-Id: Ifc0b4077c93a805898b4cd157e33172f64e85b55

added_lines: def test_modify(self): resp = Mock() resp.status_code = 200 body = None self.instances.api.client.put = Mock(return_value=(resp, body)) self.instances.modify(123) self.instances.modify(123, 321) self.instances.modify(123, 321, 123) resp.status_code = 500 self.assertRaises(Exception, self.instances.modify, 'instance1') def test_configuration(self): def side_effect_func(path, inst): return path, inst self.instances._get = Mock(side_effect=side_effect_func) self.assertEqual(('/instances/instance1/configuration', 'instance'), self.instances.configuration(1)) self.assertEqual("RESTART_REQUIRED", instances.InstanceStatus.RESTART_REQUIRED)

commit_message:
Add filter option to stack-list

Add ability to use filters on stack-list by passing a ``--filters``
options to the command line.  This option can appear multiple times or
be used once with several key=value filters separated by semicolons.  If
the same key appears more than once, both will be taken into account
when sending the request to the API.

e.g.:
The option:
``--filters status=COMPLETE;status=FAILED``
Will issue the call:
 ``/stacks?status=COMPLETE&status=FAILED``

Closes-Bug: 1268816
Change-Id: I553d6b5e3ceebdb24dcd4e4c8e409a4375d72333
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient refs/changes/85/66485/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @utils.arg('-f', '--filters', metavar='<KEY1=VALUE1;KEY2=VALUE2...>', help='Filter parameters to apply on returned stacks. ' 'This can be specified multiple times, or once with parameters ' 'separated by semicolon.', action='append') 'marker': args.marker, 'filters': utils.format_parameters(args.filters)}
deleted_lines: 'marker': args.marker}

subject: Add pagination (limit and marker) to stack-list
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-14 02:52:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient/commit/a86cbe9640f8783cf6b2f979659323a09ec83cb2', 'message': 'Add pagination (limit and marker) to stack-list

Add support for ``limit`` and ``marker`` on stack-list and remove
unnecessary ``page_size`` parameter.

When using ``limit`` and/or ``marker``, stack-list will keep previous
behavior and list all stacks starting from ``marker`` up to ``limit``,
even if limit exceeds API limit restrictions, by ussing multiple calls
to /stacks endpoint.

Partial-Bug: 1268816
Change-Id: Ifb08c1aadd3629d60ddc56ffc507c99b9dba80ce
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-01-28 19:42:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient/commit/be5bc58bb689e46c0982ce56970dd6a048b4430a', 'message': 'Add pagination (limit and marker) to stack-list

Add support for ``limit`` and ``marker`` on stack-list and remove
unnecessary ``page_size`` parameter.

When using ``limit`` and/or ``marker``, stack-list will keep previous
behavior and list all stacks starting from ``marker`` up to ``limit``,
even if limit exceeds API limit restrictions, by using multiple calls
to /stacks endpoint.

commit_message:
Add pagination (limit and marker) to stack-list

Add support for ``limit`` and ``marker`` on stack-list and remove
unnecessary ``page_size`` parameter.

When using ``limit`` and/or ``marker``, stack-list will keep previous
behavior and list all stacks starting from ``marker`` up to ``limit``,
even if limit exceeds API limit restrictions, by using multiple calls
to /stacks endpoint.

Partial-Bug: 1268816
Change-Id: Ifb08c1aadd3629d60ddc56ffc507c99b9dba80ce
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient refs/changes/84/66484/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: do_stack_list(hc) def do_list(hc): do_stack_list(hc) @utils.arg('-l', '--limit', metavar='<LIMIT>', help='Limit the number of stacks returned') @utils.arg('-m', '--marker', metavar='<ID>', help='Only return stacks that appear after the given stack ID') def do_stack_list(hc, args=None): if args: kwargs = {'limit': args.limit, 'marker': args.marker}
deleted_lines: do_list(hc) def do_list(hc, args={}): do_stack_list(hc, args) def do_stack_list(hc, args={}):

commit_message:
Fix chattr +C of VM images.

Turns out you have to chattr before you create. Weird but true.

Change-Id: Ib1483c3ec8400aa363f5e964c32cba100ed40e7e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/75/71075/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: sudo chattr +C "$volume_path" || true

commit_message:
Long overdue change to use multiple -P's with heat

The heat client change to support this has been out there a while,
lets use it.

Needs to land with Ia501bc42f821ce1cdc3f39ddee3622144ace0d8a.

Change-Id: Icfa6268a96afe10eb2754cbe1d92dd0e3ca6decb

commit_message:
Fix issue with mysql not restarting on new bind_ip

Addresses: bug #1277041

By default mysql binds to 127.0.0.1. Setting the bind_ip attribute to
something else, as we do in the ops-database cookbook before calling the
mysql::server recipe, causes the my.cnf to be populated with the correct IP.

However, because of this bug in the upstream mysql cookbook:
https://tickets.opscode.com/browse/COOK-4161
mysql does not get restarted (it only gets reloaded)
and so the new bind_ip does not take effect.

This commit adds a workaround until the upstream bug is fixed. The
workaround directly modifies the template resource from the resource
collection to add a 'restart mysql' notification.

Change-Id: I4f59e9f7fecb5040532948d0bb07d49385280a48
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-ops-database refs/changes/38/71538/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: it 'modifies my.cnf template to notify mysql restart' do file = @chef_run.template '/etc/mysql/my.cnf' expect(file).to notify("service[mysql]").to(:restart) end

commit_message:
Reintegrate devtest actions with docs.

We split this out when we just sourced things.

Now that we're fixing that and only sourcing keystone creds and cloud
endpoint details, we should expose the detail to users so they can do
this themselves.

Change-Id: Ic76b1bb7d7d6bea94c72e77c7ce4823e9f217276

one final pass through all of the cookbooks ensuring they're all in
sync with each other.

commit_message:
Update specs to be rubocop compliant

It appears orchestration was missing in the rubocop blueprints. Bringing it
up to par with the other cookbooks.

- Update rubocop config to include spec/**
- Update specs to comply with rubocop
- Delete unused default spec file

Change-Id: Ie96c16fc82a4ca2c04e20fc7db2b036937f0ba04

commit_message:
Explicitly set rpc_backend to kombu when using rabbitmq

On centos systems, /usr/share/neutron/neutron-dist.conf sets:

rpc_backend = neutron.openstack.common.rpc.impl_qpid

In order to set this correctly when using rabbit, we need to explicitly
set it in neutron.conf to override the setting in the dist file

- explicitly set rpc_backend when rabbitmq used
- add wrap around commented out zmq section

Change-Id: Ifea0ecc7ec50f7a0938b1bdd19f9da73dcb42c1e
Implements: blueprint centos-rhel-for-network
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-network refs/changes/42/70142/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: rpc_backend = neutron.openstack.common.rpc.impl_kombu

commit_message:
When debugging setup-endpoints set -x as well.

This gives more insight into whatever goes wrong when debugging is
requested.

Change-Id: I9099e0ca404c7813e9761f37842fafc90230818a

commit_message:
Stop sourcing devtest_undercloud.

Like devtest_seed, we need endpoint details and noproxy settings as
outputs from the undercloud script. By moving them into the structured
testenvironment file we can query them later without depending on an
ever moving set of environment variables. This will also support using
pre-running underclouds to run overcloud tests in CI (when we get to
that).

Change-Id: Ida6beac05c46ab5c7da8a77ae3a14fec5a39a825

commit_message:
VMware: always call methods with an open session

Method calls with an expired or closed session will return
no data. This is the root cause for a number of bugs.

Change-Id: I3716afebce2e80a62f95cbceddda0d56f798a0ed

commit_message:
Fix init of pci_stats in resource tracker

Because pci_stats is list of dict, i.e., [{}, {}, ...],
if pci_stats is null, its field should be '[]' not '{}'.

When making object models, we found this bug in PCI stuffs.

Related to blueprint pci-extra-info.

Change-Id: I06564cb541b050060e87fd3d334299df66f23dec

commit_message:
Enable hacking H233 rule

H233: Python 3.x incompatible use of print operator

Python 3 support is a good feature for OpenStack service client,
and we already have a patch for H233 but still ignore it in hacking check,
we can enable it to avoid introducing such problem again.

Change-Id: I5295ef62eef7a9f6ec7f2b67d6b68dbe2dec7067
ref: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/52841/

commit_message:
Enable default in bash completion

This adds default options to bash completion, allowing to put filenames
after options like --template-file.

Change-Id: I8881028186f26d8fccb611daabf92ba028ca41a8

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import ConfigParser import os import sys import install_venv_common as install_venv # flake8: noqa def print_help(project, venv, root): help = """ %(project)s development environment setup is complete. %(project)s development uses virtualenv to track and manage Python dependencies while in development and testing. To activate the %(project)s virtualenv for the extent of your current shell session you can run: $ source %(venv)s/bin/activate Or, if you prefer, you can run commands in the virtualenv on a case by case basis by running: $ %(root)s/tools/with_venv.sh <your command> """ print help % dict(project=project, venv=venv, root=root) def main(argv): root = os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.realpath(__file__))) if os.environ.get('tools_path'): root = os.environ['tools_path'] venv = os.path.join(root, '.venv') if os.environ.get('venv'): venv = os.environ['venv'] pip_requires = os.path.join(root, 'requirements.txt') test_requires = os.path.join(root, 'test-requirements.txt') py_version = "python%s.%s" % (sys.version_info[0], sys.version_info[1]) setup_cfg = ConfigParser.ConfigParser() setup_cfg.read('setup.cfg') project = setup_cfg.get('metadata', 'name') install = install_venv.InstallVenv( root, venv, pip_requires, test_requires, py_version, project) options = install.parse_args(argv) install.check_python_version() install.check_dependencies() install.create_virtualenv(no_site_packages=options.no_site_packages) install.install_dependencies() install.post_process() print_help(project, venv, root) if __name__ == '__main__': main(sys.argv)

commit_message:
Add ENV vars to set default and all interface roles forward

Add FORWARD_DEFAULT, MGMT_FORWARD, PRIVATE_FORWARD and STORAGE_FORWARD
 to test settings. If FORWARD_DEFAULT is defined it will become the
 default value for {ADMIN,PUBLIC,MGMT,PRIVATE,STORAGE}_FORWARD
 parameters. In it's absence the defaults are.

 ADMIN_FORWARD nat
 PUBLIC_FORWARD nat
 MGMT_FORWARD None (isolated)
 PRIVATE_FORWARD None (isolated)
 STORAGE_FORWARD None (isolated)

Closes-bug: #1275859

Change-Id: I0e5ebbb3269b02e6477323c53f6114086a225000
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/84/70784/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: FORWARD_DEFAULT = os.environ.get('FORWARD_DEFAULT', 'nat') ADMIN_FORWARD = os.environ.get('ADMIN_FORWARD', FORWARD_DEFAULT) PUBLIC_FORWARD = os.environ.get('PUBLIC_FORWARD', FORWARD_DEFAULT) MGMT_FORWARD = os.environ.get('MGMT_FORWARD', FORWARD_DEFAULT) PRIVATE_FORWARD = os.environ.get('PRIVATE_FORWARD', FORWARD_DEFAULT) STORAGE_FORWARD = os.environ.get('STORAGE_FORWARD', FORWARD_DEFAULT) 'management': MGMT_FORWARD, 'private': PRIVATE_FORWARD, 'storage': STORAGE_FORWARD,
deleted_lines: ADMIN_FORWARD = os.environ.get('ADMIN_FORWARD', 'nat') PUBLIC_FORWARD = os.environ.get('PUBLIC_FORWARD', 'nat') 'management': None, 'private': None, 'storage': None,

commit_message:
Fix un-changeable resource in l3_if_downup

The previous patch attempted to change @resource[:wait_carrier_after_ifup]
 this dosn't work. This patch changes this to create a new variable to test
 before entering into the carrier wait loop

Change-Id: I1f6e8d8eff253dc665a66bf64f1d2ecfedb1f63a
Related-bug: #1275132
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/79/71079/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: poll_for_carrier = false else poll_for_carrier = true if (@resource[:interface] =~ /^eth\d+$/) and @resource[:wait_carrier_after_ifup] and poll_for_carrier
deleted_lines: @resource[:wait_carrier_after_ifup] = false if (@resource[:interface] =~ /^eth\d+$/) and @resource[:wait_carrier_after_ifup]

commit_message:
Return correct HTTP response codes for create ops

When creating {chassis,node,port} resources the incorrect HTTP
response code was being returned. (was 200, now returning 201).

Closes-Bug: #1272596

Change-Id: Ic0fb2cc1794841dcef7009990f0ae482d71b1242

added_lines: from solum.objects import baseclass Application(base.CrudMixin): class ApplicationList(list, base.CrudListMixin): """List of Application."""
deleted_lines: class Application(object): @classmethod def get_by_id(cls, context, id): """Return a specific object by its unique identifier.""" def create(self, context): """Create the application.""" def save(self, context): """Change the application.""" def destroy(self, context): """Destroy the application.""" def add_forward_schema_changes(self): """Update the attributes of self to include new schema elements. This method is invoked during save/create operations to guarantee that objects being created during a schema transition support both new and old schemas. This ensures that background jobs can run to migrate existing objects on a live system while writes are occurring. The changes made by this method must match the schema defined for "transitioning" and "new" (see solum.objects.__init__). """ class ApplicationList(list): @classmethod def get_all(cls, context): """Retrieve all applications for the active context. Context may be global or tenant scoped. """

commit_message:
Update Debian to use /etc/network/interfaces.d

Updates the dhcp-all-interfaces.sh script so that we use
interfaces.d for ENI files. This change is useful for
several reasons:

 1) we need the ability to overwrite the DHCP config file for a
  specific interface when it is moved onto an OVS bridge.  This
  is important for our TripleO neutron initialization changes in
  this branch where we will use a similar approach:

    https://review.openstack.org/#/c/69918/

 2) it makes it possible to disable an interface that is unplugged

Change-Id: I537b4df1c7a2431bacebe6e4aa7576d17d17a16f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/35/69935/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
if ! grep '^source /etc/network/interfaces.d' $ENI_FILE; then printf "source /etc/network/interfaces.d/*.cfg
" >>$ENI_FILE fi printf "auto $interface
iface $interface inet dhcp

" >> /etc/network/interfaces.d/${interface}.cfg local config_file="" config_file="/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-$interface" elif [ "$CONF_TYPE" == "eni" ]; then config_file="/etc/network/interfaces.d/${interface}.cfg" fi if [ -f "$config_file" ]; then rm $config_file
deleted_lines:
printf "auto $interface
iface $interface inet dhcp

" >>$ENI_FILE local IFCFG_FILE="/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-$interface" if [ -f "$IFCFG_FILE" ]; then rm $IFCFG_FILE else echo "No link detected, skipping" fi

commit_message:
Start renaming oslo.sphinx to oslosphinx

Add oslosphinx in addition to oslo.sphinx so we can update
consuming projects before removing oslo.sphinx from the
dependency list.

Partial-bug: #1277168

Change-id: I7788a9d6b5984fdfcc4678f2182104d2eb8a2be0

commit_message:
Removes logging of location uri

This patch removes logging of sensitive store location uri, which
is logged when an exception occurs while trying to get the object
from the store or due to a failure in getting the store api due to
unauthorized context.

fixes bug 1275062

Change-Id: I679baa0897f242f4b8372c9c1c7ab28ae811f5e5

commit_message:
Add a new chapter for upgrades

This chapter is probably the most-requested document in
all of OpenStack. Let's see if we can do it.

* pre-upgrade testing
* steps to upgrade Compute and Networking grizzly-->havana

Do not merge until testing is done.

Change-Id: Ic27b98c30dec278746c22f434e32ed677247f8a9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/operations-guide refs/changes/36/68936/19 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: <section xml:id="upgrades"> <?dbhtml stop-chunking?> <title>Upgrades</title> <para>With the exception of Object Storage, an upgrade from one version of OpenStack to another is a great deal of work.</para> <para>The upgrade process generally follows these steps:</para> <orderedlist> <listitem> <para>Read the release notes and documentation.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Find incompatibilities between different versions.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Plan an upgrade schedule and complete it in order on a test cluster.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Run the upgrade.</para> </listitem> </orderedlist> <para>You can perform an upgrade while user instances run. However, this strategy can be dangerous. Don't forget appropriate notice to your users, and backups.</para> <para>The general order that seems to be most successful is:</para> <orderedlist> <listitem> <para>Upgrade the OpenStack Identity service (keystone).</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Upgrade the OpenStack Image service (glance).</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Upgrade all OpenStack Compute (nova) services.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Upgrade all OpenStack Block Storage (cinder) services.</para> </listitem> </orderedlist> <para>For each of these steps, complete the following sub-steps:</para> <orderedlist> <listitem> <para>Stop services.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Create a backup of configuration files and databases.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Upgrade the packages using your distribution's package manager.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Update the configuration files according to the release notes.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Apply the database upgrades.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Restart the services.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Verify that everything is running.</para> </listitem> </orderedlist> <para>Probably the most important step of all is the pre-upgrade testing. Especially if you are upgrading immediately after release of a new version, undiscovered bugs might hinder your progress. Some deployers prefer to wait until the first point release is announced. However, if you have a significant deployment, you might follow the development and testing of the release, thereby ensuring that bugs for your use cases are fixed.</para> <para>To complete an upgrade of OpenStack Compute while keeping instances running, you should be able to use live migration to move machines around while performing updates, and then move them back afterward as this is a property of the hypervisor. However, it is critical to ensure that database changes are successful otherwise an inconsistent cluster state could arise.</para> <para>Performing some 'cleaning' of the cluster prior to starting the upgrade is also a good idea, to ensure the state is consistent. For example some have reported issues with instances that were not fully removed from the system after their deletion. Running a command equivalent to: <screen><prompt>$</prompt> <userinput>virsh list --all</userinput></screen> to find deleted instances that are still registered in the hypervisor and removing them prior to running the upgrade can avoid issues. </para> </section>

commit_message:
Add vagrantfile/environment for a working vagrant all-in-one using
nova-network

Implements: blueprint reference-havana-vagrant

- remove unused attrs from previous example vagrant.rb, and change to
  vagrant-aio-nova.json
- add Vagrantfile-aio-nova targeted specifically at an allinone using
  nova-network (other vagrantfiles can cover other deployments)
- Update CentOS box to 6.5
- Remove Vagrantfile and environments/vagrant.rb to avoid confusion
- allow multiple simultaneous vagrant up with different chef-zero
  servers
- add usage comments at top of file

Change-Id: I9e4145dd1f22efa7e423794bb122bde756884f40
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-chef-repo refs/changes/85/69385/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: { "name": "vagrant-aio", "description": "", "cookbook_versions": { }, "json_class": "Chef::Environment", "chef_type": "environment", "default_attributes": { }, "override_attributes": { "openstack": { "developer_mode": true, "image": { "image_upload": true, "upload_images": [ "cirros" ], "upload_image": { "cirros": "https://launchpad.net/cirros/trunk/0.3.0/+download/cirros-0.3.0-x86_64-disk.img" } }, "compute": { "network": { "public_interface": "eth1" }, "config": { "ram_allocation_ratio": 5.0 }, "libvirt": { "virt_type": "qemu" }, "networks": [ { "label": "public", "ipv4_cidr": "192.168.100.0/24", "num_networks": "1", "network_size": "255", "bridge": "br100", "bridge_dev": "eth1", "dns1": "8.8.8.8", "dns2": "8.8.4.4" } ] } } } }

subject: Better socket termination for ZeroMQ
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-06-20 20:39:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/9b3687d907e3b095b80cee577b8c238b3c3e9fcf', 'message': "Better socket termination for ZeroMQ

We were telling ZeroMQ to close sockets,
but only after successfully sending them.
If a socket timed out, we'd drop the reference
from Python, but the ZeroMQ library was still
keeping these sockets alive in the background.

Instead of using eventlet's Timeout,
we can simply use the linger argument to
terminate sockets if they're alive for too
