commit_message:
Move failover tests to seperate package

The tests were in test_ha.py. There was a decision
to move these tests to seperate package called
test_strength

Change-Id: Ib6551c4841fd636de6ef5d6bc704187a79b33129
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/91/71291/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2013 Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import logging import re from devops.error import DevopsCalledProcessError from devops.helpers.helpers import wait from proboscis import test from proboscis.asserts import assert_true, assert_equal, assert_not_equal from fuelweb_test.helpers.decorators import debug, log_snapshot_on_error from fuelweb_test.settings import DEPLOYMENT_MODE_HA from fuelweb_test.tests.base_test_case import TestBasic, SetupEnvironment logger = logging.getLogger(__name__) logwrap = debug(logger) @test(groups=["thread_5", "ha"]) class TestHaFailover(TestBasic): @test(depends_on=[SetupEnvironment.prepare_slaves_5], groups=["deploy_ha"]) @log_snapshot_on_error def deploy_ha(self): """Deploy cluster in HA mode with flat nova-network Scenario: 1. Create cluster 2. Add 3 nodes with controller roles 3. Add 2 nodes with compute roles 4. Deploy the cluster 8. Make snapshot Snapshot deploy_ha """ self.env.revert_snapshot("ready_with_5_slaves") cluster_id = self.fuel_web.create_cluster( name=self.__class__.__name__, mode=DEPLOYMENT_MODE_HA ) self.fuel_web.update_nodes( cluster_id, { 'slave-01': ['controller'], 'slave-02': ['controller'], 'slave-03': ['controller'], 'slave-04': ['compute'], 'slave-05': ['compute'] } ) self.fuel_web.deploy_cluster_wait(cluster_id) self.env.make_snapshot("deploy_ha") @test(depends_on_groups=['deploy_ha'], groups=["ha_destroy_controllers"]) @log_snapshot_on_error def ha_destroy_controllers(self): """Destory two controllers and check pacemaker status is correct Scenario: 1. Destroy first controller 2. Check pacemaker status 3. Revert environment 4. Destroy second controller 5. Check pacemaker status Snapshot deploy_ha """ for devops_node in self.env.nodes().slaves[:2]: self.env.revert_snapshot("deploy_ha") devops_node.suspend(False) self.fuel_web.assert_pacemaker( self.env.nodes().slaves[2].name, set(self.env.nodes().slaves[:3]) - {devops_node}, [devops_node]) @test(depends_on_groups=['deploy_ha'], groups=["ha_disconnect_controllers"]) @log_snapshot_on_error def ha_disconnect_controllers(self): """Disconnect controllers and check pacemaker status is correct Scenario: 1. Disconnect eth3 of the first controller 2. Check pacemaker status 3. Revert environment 4. Disconnect eth3 of the second controller 5. Check pacemaker status Snapshot deploy_ha """ for devops_node in self.env.nodes().slaves[:2]: self.env.revert_snapshot("deploy_ha") remote = self.fuel_web.get_ssh_for_node(devops_node.name) remote.check_call('ifconfig eth2 down') self.fuel_web.assert_pacemaker( self.env.nodes().slaves[2].name, set(self.env.nodes().slaves[:3]) - {devops_node}, [devops_node]) @test(depends_on_groups=['deploy_ha'], groups=["ha_delete_vips"]) @log_snapshot_on_error def ha_delete_vips(self): """Delete all secondary VIPs on all controller nodes. Verify that they are restored. Verify total amount of secondary IPs. Should be 2: management and public Scenario: 1. Delete all secondary VIP 2. Wait while it is being restored 3. Verify it is restored Snapshot deploy_ha """ self.env.revert_snapshot("deploy_ha") # Verify VIPs are started. ret = self.fuel_web.get_pacemaker_status( self.env.nodes().slaves[0].name) assert_true( re.search('vip__management_old\s+\(ocf::heartbeat:IPaddr2\):' '\s+Started node', ret), 'vip management started') assert_true( re.search('vip__public_old\s+\(ocf::heartbeat:IPaddr2\):' '\s+Started node', ret), 'vip public started') interfaces = ('eth1', 'eth2') ips_amount = 0 for devops_node in self.env.nodes().slaves[:3]: for interface in interfaces: try: # Look for secondary ip and remove it addresses = self.fuel_web.ip_address_show( devops_node.name, interface) ip = re.search( 'inet (?P<ip>\d+\.\d+\.\d+.\d+/\d+) brd ' '(?P<mask>\d+\.\d+\.\d+.\d+) scope global secondary', addresses).group('ip') self.fuel_web.ip_address_del( devops_node.name, interface, ip) # The ip should be restored ip_assigned = \ lambda: ip in self.fuel_web.ip_address_show( devops_node.name, interface) wait(ip_assigned, timeout=10) assert_true(ip_assigned(), 'Secondary IP is restored') ips_amount += 1 except DevopsCalledProcessError: pass assert_equal(ips_amount, 2, 'Secondary IPs amount') @test(depends_on_groups=['deploy_ha'], groups=["ha_mysql_termination"]) @log_snapshot_on_error def ha_mysql_termination(self): """Terminate mysql on all controllers one by one Scenario: 1. Terminate mysql 2. Wait while it is being restarted 3. Verify it is restarted 4. Go to another controller Snapshot deploy_ha """ self.env.revert_snapshot("deploy_ha") for devops_node in self.env.nodes().slaves[:3]: remote = self.fuel_web.get_ssh_for_node(devops_node.name) remote.check_call('kill -9 $(pidof -x mysqld_safe)') remote.check_call('kill -9 $(pidof mysqld)') mysql_started = lambda: \ len(remote.check_call( 'ps aux | grep "/usr/sbin/mysql"')['stdout']) == 3 wait(mysql_started, timeout=300) assert_true(mysql_started(), 'MySQL restarted') @test(depends_on_groups=['deploy_ha'], groups=["ha_haproxy_termination"]) @log_snapshot_on_error def ha_haproxy_termination(self): """Terminate haproxy on all controllers one by one Scenario: 1. Terminate haproxy 2. Wait while it is being restarted 3. Verify it is restarted 4. Go to another controller Snapshot deploy_ha """ self.env.revert_snapshot("deploy_ha") for devops_node in self.env.nodes().slaves[:3]: remote = self.fuel_web.get_ssh_for_node(devops_node.name) remote.check_call('kill -9 $(pidof haproxy)') mysql_started = lambda: \ len(remote.check_call( 'ps aux | grep "/usr/sbin/haproxy"')['stdout']) == 3 wait(mysql_started, timeout=20) assert_true(mysql_started(), 'haproxy restarted') @test(depends_on_groups=['deploy_ha'], groups=["ha_pacemaker_configuration"]) @log_snapshot_on_error def ha_pacemaker_configuration(self): """Verify resources are configured Scenario: 1. SSH to controller node 2. Verify resources are configured 3. Go to next controller Snapshot deploy_ha """ self.env.revert_snapshot("deploy_ha") devops_ctrls = self.env.nodes().slaves[:3] for devops_node in devops_ctrls: config = self.fuel_web.get_pacemaker_config(devops_node.name) for n in devops_ctrls: fqdn = self.fuel_web.fqdn(n) assert_true( 'node {0}'.format(fqdn) in config, 'node {0} exists'.format(fqdn)) assert_not_equal( re.search('primitive (openstack-)?heat-engine', config), None, 'heat engine') assert_true('primitive p_haproxy' in config, 'haproxy') assert_true('primitive p_mysql' in config, 'mysql') assert_true( 'primitive vip__management_old' in config, 'vip management') assert_true( 'primitive vip__public_old' in config, 'vip public')

commit_message:
XenAPI: Use get_VALUE in preference to get_record()['VALUE']

Replaces calls to get_record where only a single item is retrieved
from the record with the specific get_VALUE call.

Change-Id: I52e20c4f4c9d6a6ad019694916ee057cc96b18a6

commit_message:
Clean/leave OpenStack after a stress test

New parameter "leave_dirty_stack" available in tempest.conf
to prevent (or not) the execution of tearDownClass()
after an exception during a stress test

Closes-Bug: #1273245
Change-Id: I89ecac1fb428cf8809a3634869f2dfdf564aea64
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/41/69641/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Bug 1273245 : allows running tearDownClass() if an exception occured # if the "leave_dirty_stack" parameter is set to false in tempest.conf try: self.run_core() except Exception as e: raise e finally: if (self.manager.config.stress.leave_dirty_stack is False and self.class_setup_per == SetUpClassRunTime.action): self.klass.tearDownClass()
deleted_lines: self.run_core() if (self.class_setup_per == SetUpClassRunTime.action): self.klass.tearDownClass()

commit_message:
Improve forbidden checks

New functions were created to check 'allowed' access because the previous design
was checking after changes were possibly made.

Changed the unit test to use an already created user to simulate the original
error that was reported.

Change-Id: I9f7e56a5afd9624070fffef6672ef88cd549f210
Closes-Bug: #1174451

This patch creates race condition issues in the Hyper-V driver

commit_message:
Revert "Allow deleting instances while uuid lock is held"

This reverts commit 08beabc5e0fc3fffc074a634040f5821d4d1d5f2.

This patch creates race condition issues in the Hyper-V driver
due to the fact that spawn, destroy and other methods have been
written with the instance lock in mind.

In this context, thread safety needs to be enforced where needed
in all drivers before this patch can be applied.

Sample Hyper-V CI log showing the error:
http://64.119.130.115/63217/7/Hyper-V/hv-compute2/nova-compute.log.gz

Partial-Bug: #1276772

Change-Id: I72fb1f9de7767b7206c5fa39b87216fa3f1b5c68

commit_message:
Generate streaming tag in mapreduce job

If the configuration values indicate streaming for a mapreduce
job, then generate the <streaming> tag in the workflow with the
specified mapper and reducer values.

Implements: blueprint edp-oozie-streaming-mapreduce
Change-Id: I53926b1d7a1eeff83ca60d1224882e229ded35c3

subject: Updates cinder-group-active script to work on Ubuntu
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-30 05:31:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-block-storage/commit/6c01da0ab1001dd52c6fe6d27ec89e0d928353f3', 'message': "Updates cinder-group-active script to work on Ubuntu

Setting the following attribute to true causes a chef-client to fail on
Ubuntu:

default['openstack']['block-storage']['volume']['create_volume_group']

The reason is that when this is enabled, the file cinder-group-active
is dropped in /etc/init.d and attempting to start it fails since it's
not written for Ubuntu.  This change wraps some of the Red Hat specific
bits with if statements and also conditionally runs the vgcreate so we
don't run losetup unnecessarily (which keeps mapping the volume file to
new /dev/loop devices).

commit_message:
Updates cinder-group-active script to work on Ubuntu

Setting the following attribute to true causes a chef-client to fail on
Ubuntu:

default['openstack']['block-storage']['volume']['create_volume_group']

The reason is that when this is enabled, the file cinder-group-active
is dropped in /etc/init.d and attempting to start it fails since it's
not written for Ubuntu.  This change wraps some of the Red Hat specific
bits with if statements and also conditionally runs the vgcreate so we
don't run losetup unnecessarily (which keeps mapping the volume file to
new /dev/loop devices).

Change-Id: I5e14aeec64b1c1d596584bfc5d3352f45114421a

commit_message:
Extract configs beginning with "edp." from job_configs['configs']

Allow configuration parameters beginning with "edp." to be extracted
from the job configuration during workflow generation. This provides
a consistent, extensible method for passing job-type specific settings
to Savanna which impact the workflow (but which do not appear in the
<configuration/> section of the workflow).

Implements: blueprint edp-config-parameter-prefix

Change-Id: I9641f8f84a4807646940e43e92370faae3460609

Upgrade/Update rubocop

Now that almost all of the rubocop blueprints have been completed, make
one final pass through all of the cookbooks ensuring they're all in
sync with each other.

- Upgrade rubocop to 0.18.1

  automatically cover future additions

commit_message:
Remove get_instance_type and get_active_by_window from nova compute API

Commit 013b301c1c makes both methods vestigial since the
simple_tenant_usage API was the only thing using them.

Change-Id: Idbe8183760edd57b58564761c30f2f6e3ad0086e

commit_message:
Upgrade/Update rubocop

Now that almost all of the rubocop blueprints have been completed, make
one final pass through all of the cookbooks ensuring they're all in
sync with each other.

- Upgrade rubocop to 0.18.1
- Fix violations caused by 0.18.1 upgrade
- Move Excludes for non-existent folders to Includes so they
  automatically cover future additions

Change-Id: I1e984e4dd496977d29f483199b3b091f1481dc47
Implements: blueprint lint-and-unit-testing-for-havana

commit_message:
Small tweak to the wordcount example README

Mention that the UI will prompt for main_class and java_opts. The
fact that these are set via "edp." parameters doesn't matter
because the UI will mask that fact from the user.

Change-Id: I1e3e273a7346944c10b68ea9401bb69e1fe60f64

commit_message:
Make rbd_secret_uuid behave like a shared secret

This change makes rbd_secret_uuid behave like neutron_metadata_secret,
since it basically fulfills the same role in the exchange between cinder
and nova-compute.

Implements: blueprint rbd-for-block-storage

Change-Id: I7bda1c5e36ce661df70bdf91a70cbb2b2c8b6ac6

Now that almost all of the rubocop blueprints have been completed, make
one final pass through all of the cookbooks ensuring they're all in
sync with each other.

commit_message:
Add documentation for pipeline configuration

Extend the configuration section of the development documentation
of Ceilometer to contain the configuration options of pipelines.

Change-Id: Ie033431716b32a41040d5b4738e6ba150c2c9da8
Closes-Bug: #1272988
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/50/69350/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Pipelines ========= Pipelines describe chains of handlers, which can be transformers and/or publishers. The chain can start with a transformer, which is responsible to convert the data coming from the collectors to the required format, which can mean dropping some parts of the sample, doing aggregation or changing field, etc. The pipeline can contain multiple transformers or none at all. The chains end with one or more publishers. This component makes it possible to persist the data into storage through the message bus or to send it to one or more external consumers. One chain can contain multiple publishers, see the :ref:`multi-publisher` section. Pipeline configuration ---------------------- Pipeline configuration by default, is stored in a separate configuration file, called pipeline.yaml, next to the ceilometer.conf file. The pipeline configuration file can be set in the *pipeline_cfg_file* parameter in ceilometer.conf. Multiple chains can be defined in one configuration file. The chain definition looks like the following:: --- - name: 'name of the pipeline' interval: 'how often should the samples be injected into the pipeline' meters: - 'meter filter' transformers: 'definition of transformers' publishers: - 'list of publishers' The *interval* should be defined in seconds. There are several ways to define the list of meters for a pipeline. The list of valid meters can be found in the :ref:`measurements` section. There is a possibility to define all the meters, or just included or excluded meters, with which a pipeline should operate: * To include all meters, use the '*' wildcard symbol. * To define the list of meters, use either of the following: * To define the list of included meters, use the 'meter_name' syntax * To define the list of excluded meters, use the '!meter_name' syntax * For meters, which identify a complex Sample field, use the wildcard symbol to select all, e.g. for "instance:m1.tiny", use "instance:\*" The above definition methods can be used in the following combinations: * Only the wildcard symbol * The list of included meters * The list of excluded meters * Wildcard symbol with the list of excluded meters .. note:: At least one of the above variations should be included in the meters section. Included and excluded meters cannot co-exist in the same pipeline. Wildcard and included meters cannot co-exist in the same pipeline definition section. The *transformers* section provides the possibility to add a list of transformer definitions. The names of the transformers should be the same as the names of the related extensions in setup.cfg. The definition of transformers can contain the following fields:: transformers: - name: 'name of the transformer' parameters: The *parameters* section can contain transformer specific fields, like source and target fields with different subfields in case of the rate_of_change, which depends on the implementation of the transformer. In case of the transformer, which creates the *cpu_util* meter, the definition looks like the following:: transformers: - name: "rate_of_change" parameters: target: name: "cpu_util" unit: "%" type: "gauge" scale: "100.0 / (10**9 * (resource_metadata.cpu_number or 1))" The *rate_of_change* transformer generates the *cpu_util* meter from the sample values of the *cpu* counter, which represents cumulative CPU time in nanoseconds. The transformer definition above defines a scale factor (for nanoseconds, multiple CPUs, etc.), which is applied before the transformation derives a sequence of gauge samples with unit '%', from the original values of the *cpu* meter. The definition for the disk utilization rate, which is also generated by the *rate_of_change* transformer:: transformers: - name: "rate_of_change" parameters: source: map_from: name: "disk\\.(read|write)\\.(bytes|requests)" unit: "(B|request)" target: map_to: name: "disk.\\1.\\2.rate" unit: "\\1/s" type: "gauge" The *publishers* section contains the list of publishers, where the samples data should be sent after the possible transformations. The names of the publishers should be the same as the related names of the plugins in setup.cfg. The default configuration can be found in `pipeline.yaml`_. .. _pipeline.yaml: https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/ceilometer/tree/etc/ceilometer/pipeline.yaml

commit_message:
Use requests library in S3 middleware

Convert the S3 token middleware to use the requests library. It does not
validate certificates as part of this patch to keep new functionality
isolated.

Change-Id: I0f26c80a969b919de80410af0a80920bd8493191
Closes-Bug: #1275598
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/47/70647/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import requests auth_host = conf.get('auth_host') auth_port = int(conf.get('auth_port', 35357)) auth_protocol = conf.get('auth_protocol', 'https') self.request_uri = '%s://%s:%s' % (auth_protocol, auth_host, auth_port) cert_file = conf.get('certfile') key_file = conf.get('keyfile') if cert_file and key_file: self.verify = (cert_file, key_file) elif cert_file: self.verify = cert_file else: # FIXME(jamielennox): This is a bad default! This behaviour is kept # because it's compatible with the original httplib implementation # but it should be corrected as soon as possible. self.verify = False try: response = requests.post('%s/v2.0/s3tokens' % self.request_uri, headers=headers, data=creds_json, allow_redirects=False) except requests.exceptions.RequestException as e: if response.status_code < 200 or response.status_code >= 300: (response.status_code, response.reason)) return response resp = self._json_request(creds_json) self.logger.debug(msg % (resp.status_code)) resp.status_code, resp.text)) identity_info = jsonutils.loads(resp.text) self.logger.debug(error % (resp.status_code, str(resp.text)))
deleted_lines: import httplib self.auth_host = conf.get('auth_host') self.auth_port = int(conf.get('auth_port', 35357)) self.auth_protocol = conf.get('auth_protocol', 'https') if self.auth_protocol == 'http': self.http_client_class = httplib.HTTPConnection else: self.http_client_class = httplib.HTTPSConnection self.cert_file = conf.get('certfile') self.key_file = conf.get('keyfile') if self.auth_protocol == 'http': conn = self.http_client_class(self.auth_host, self.auth_port) else: conn = self.http_client_class(self.auth_host, self.auth_port, self.key_file, self.cert_file) try: conn.request('POST', '/v2.0/s3tokens', body=creds_json, headers=headers) response = conn.getresponse() output = response.read() except Exception as e: finally: conn.close() if response.status < 200 or response.status >= 300: (response.status, response.reason)) return (response, output) resp, output = self._json_request(creds_json) self.logger.debug(msg % (resp.status)) resp.status, output)) identity_info = jsonutils.loads(output) self.logger.debug(error % (resp.status, str(output)))

commit_message:
VMware: use .get() to access 'summary.accessible'

the key 'summary.accessible' is not always present in
property-sets hence use .get() instead of []

Change-Id: Ia291b39d1322c486be13f677a816168b501de3fb
Closes-Bug: 1252400

commit_message:
Add option for enabling debug logs only for OpenStack

A new option --debug-openstack was introduced to enable debug logs for
OpenStack components, but not for external ones (e.g. ampq).

Change-Id: Ifccd47cd36db5e7e1693a9be11da2810ca71c2c1
Closes-Bug: #1207576
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/22/64022/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.BoolOpt('debug-openstack-only', default=False, help='Print debugging output only for OpenStack components, ' 'but not for third party libraries.'), if CONF.debug and not CONF.debug_openstack_only: logger = logging.getLogger(name) # In some places root logger is also accessed via this function, # but we should not set debug level on it. if CONF.debug_openstack_only and logger is not logging.getLogger(): logger.setLevel(logging.DEBUG) _loggers[name] = ContextAdapter(logger, name, version)
deleted_lines: if CONF.debug: _loggers[name] = ContextAdapter(logging.getLogger(name), name, version)

commit_message:
Add validate() base method

Now that all backends implement a validate that
can be called to check if the backend is still
useable we can add a base method to the base class
that defines exactly what this new method does.

Change-Id: Ica4571970bad2de16ce2071a645abf24c25c110b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/53/71453/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def validate(self): """Validates that a backend is still ok to be used (the semantics of this vary depending on the backend). On failure a backend specific exception is raised that will indicate why the failure occurred. """ pass @abc.abstractmethod

commit_message:
Disable libvirt driver file injection by default

DocImpact: This changes the default for file injection and key
injection with the libvirt driver. Most people should not need file
injection (the metadata server and/or config drive are more robust,
better options).

UpgradeImpact

blueprint disable-file-injection-by-default

Change-Id: Icff1304fc816acc843f8962727aef8bbbc7bbaa3
Co-Authored-By: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Steve Kowalik <steven@wedontsleep.org>

commit_message:
Logging excepthook: print exception info if debug=True

Sync from Oslo: I349dc76320911600accc2acdb02d9d94710cfc85

Exception info is only printed by this function if verbose=True.
Since debug is considered a log level with more information than
verbose (INFO), exception info should also be printed when only
debug=True.

Change-Id: I3056188f5ec90fc3f04734b9fa01c6e968b52ec1

commit_message:
Configure security group when using ML2 plugin

Since the ML2 plugin can concurrently support different L2 agents (or
other mechanisms) with different configurations, Neutron developpers recommend
setting firewall_driver flag in ml2 configuration.

Change-Id: I62d0d1b2aac88a11e5f3e80e98953c71cfc98629
Closes-bug: #1262678
Signed-off-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien.macchi@enovance.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron refs/changes/28/63228/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [*enable_security_group*] # (optionnal) Enable the security group API or not. # Since the ML2 plugin can concurrently support different L2 agents (or other # mechanisms) with different configurations, we need to set something to the # firewall_driver flag to enable security group API. # Defaults to true. $vni_ranges = ['10:100'], $enable_security_group = true if $enable_security_group { neutron_plugin_ml2 { 'securitygroup/firewall_driver': value => $enable_security_group; } } else { neutron_plugin_ml2 { 'securitygroup/firewall_driver': ensure => absent; } }
deleted_lines: $vni_ranges = ['10:100']

commit_message:
Handle multiple exceptions raised by jsonpatch

The jsonpatch.apply_patch() might raise different types of exceptions,
this patch improve the exception handler on the jsonpatch.apply_patch()
call to capture them and also creates a new exception called PatchError
to avoid replicating the same error message across the resources.

The patch also doesn't log the exception raised by the apply_patch()
anymore, since the problem will be returned to the client directly via
the API response.

In the chassis.py an alias "api_utils" was created to the utils module
to be more consistent with the ports and nodes resource.

Closes-Bug: #1271554
Change-Id: Ied1f5e573839520cc5f4e04548720f016f33349b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/57/68457/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: except api_utils.jsonpatch_exceptions as e: raise exception.PatchError(patch=patch, reason=e)
deleted_lines: except jsonpatch.JsonPatchException as e: LOG.exception(e) raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError(_("Patching Error: %s") % e)

commit_message:
API tests to check for the return codes

Some API tests were just checking whether a particular request would
raise a generic exception (webtest.app.AppError) or not, and this is not
enough, the API tests should make sure that the request will raise an
exception (expect_errors=True) and also check if the HTTP code returned
is appropriated for that error.

The FIXME left at test_remove_fail() is going to be fixed by a following
patch.

Closes-Bug: #1275812
Change-Id: I156749b3de0627c6d322192c397bbfe33919cf2d

commit_message:
Add the db schema for the application table

This is just providing the basic db columns needed for
solum/objects/sqlalchemy/application.py.

The initial file was generated with:
$ solum-db-manage revision -m "Add application"

Change-Id: I7bc914c12284041b14a414c333eb05d427ac5b2e

'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2014-01-08 16:23:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/2f46ca65af579601aa2460510b5792ca7621466f', 'message': 'Multiversion authentication part1

WIP - do not merge

Removes authentication from rest_client classes;
rest_clients are create with a callable that provides
base_url and token based on endpoint_type.
The callable moves the auth resposibility to an auth
provider, and it allows to delay auth and endpoint
selection to the point where the client is actually
being used.

Fixes endpoint_type selection for v3 auth.
Drops unused basic_auth.
Fixes previously unused and broken TokenClients.

Makes manager.py the auth provider. Manager class uses
the fixed TokenClients to obtain v2 and v3 tokens.
Manager caches auth data, it keeps one token per
(auth version, interface type) combination to handle
all clients managed by it.
Authentication is done for both JSON and XML, so that
we test the token interace for both interface types.

Introduces a configuration parameter for
authentication version to be used. That is used when
instantiating the client manager, and it applies
to all clients used by api tests.

Removes redundant server_client_v3_auth.

Partially implements:
bp multi-keystone-api-version-tests

Change-Id: Icfa921e9051c01f339f8d2471b12d6ec950cc456
'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2014-01-08 16:30:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/a307a64d6e44dab2c2ff0fd8411fbb96753dff44', 'message': 'Multiversion authentication part1

WIP - do not merge

Removes authentication from rest_client classes;
rest_clients are create with a callable that provides
base_url and token based on endpoint_type.
The callable moves the auth resposibility to an auth
provider, and it allows to delay auth and endpoint
selection to the point where the client is actually
being used.

Fixes endpoint_type selection for v3 auth.
Drops unused basic_auth.
Fixes previously unused and broken TokenClients.
Adapts tempest unit tests to work with
modified rest client.

Makes manager.py the auth provider. Manager class uses
the fixed TokenClients to obtain v2 and v3 tokens.
Manager caches auth data, it keeps one token per
(auth version, interface type) combination to handle
all clients managed by it.
Authentication is done for both JSON and XML, so that
we test the token interace for both interface types.

Introduces a configuration parameter for
authentication version to be used. That is used when
instantiating the client manager, and it applies
to all clients used by api tests.

Removes redundant server_client_v3_auth.

Partially implements:
bp multi-keystone-api-version-tests

Change-Id: Icfa921e9051c01f339f8d2471b12d6ec950cc456

'}, {'number': 8, 'created': '2014-01-10 18:59:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/71ba09392b8f1e9a521610b21224aeab7ec6afe1', 'message': 'Multiversion authentication part1

WIP - do not merge

Removes authentication from rest_client classes;
rest_clients are create with a callable that returns
a dict with auth data (base_url, token, username,
tenant name) based on endpoint_type.
The callable moves the auth resposibility to an auth
provider, and it allows to delay auth and endpoint
selection to the point where the client is actually
being used.

Fixes endpoint_type selection for v3 auth.
Drops unused basic_auth.
Fixes previously unused and broken TokenClients.
Adapts tempest unit tests to work with
modified rest client.

Makes manager.py the auth provider. Manager class uses
the fixed TokenClients to obtain v2 and v3 tokens.
Manager caches auth data, it keeps one token per
(auth version, interface type) combination to handle
all clients managed by it.
Authentication is done for both JSON and XML, so that
we test the token interace for both interface types.

Introduces a configuration parameter for
authentication version to be used. That is used when
instantiating the client manager, and it applies
to all clients used by api tests.

Removes redundant server_client_v3_auth.

bp multi-keystone-api-version-tests

'}, {'number': 9, 'created': '2014-01-16 16:00:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/4b22fbf8d15335afb24a995093174330629dd36f', 'message': 'Multiversion authentication part1

WIP - do not merge

Removes authentication from rest_client classes;
rest_clients are create with an instance of an auth
provider.

The auth provider can decorate a request based on
credentials and filters (region, service, endpoint_type).
The auth provider can also return the raw auth_data,
which in the Keystone implementation is a tuple
(token, auth_data), obtained from the token API call.
The auth provider moves the auth resposibility out of
the rest client, and it allows to delay auth and endpoint
selection to the point where the client is actually
being used.
The auth provider allows mixing multiple credentials
when decorating a request, possibly using empty or
invalid credentials, to facilitate negative tests.

The auth provider caches auth data, so that all API
requests for a specific set of credentials only require
a single call to obtain a token, unless the token
expires or is forcefully deleted from the auth provder.

Two implementations of the auth provider are included:
Keystonev2 and Keystonev3.  The Manager object behaves
as factory of auth_providers, building the correct one
based on the configured auth_version, and on the
interafce type (JSON or XML).

Fixes endpoint_type selection for v3 auth.
Drops unused basic_auth.
Extends TokenClients into AuthClienats to provide both token
and auth data, as well as accept XML reply for XML requests.

Adapts tempest unit tests to work with modified rest client.
Adapts object-storage test to not set auth directly, and
use the auth provider instead. In fact the "custom" flavor
of the object-storage clientis is made redundant by this
change, but I will remove them in a next patch to keep
this one to a manageable size.

Introduces a configuration parameter for
authentication version to be used. That is used when
instantiating the client manager, and it applies
to all clients used by api tests.

Removes redundant server_client_v3_auth.

Next steps (this patch):
- extend v3 token client rather than rewriting it
- align image v1/v2 client to use auth provider
- align object storage client to use auth provider

Next steps (next patches):
- move to credentials as dict (as opposed to tuple)
- supports keystone v3 in tenant isolation
- use Auth Provider in scenario tests
- use Auth Provider in CLI tests

Partially implements:
bp multi-keystone-api-version-tests

Change-Id: Icfa921e9051c01f339f8d2471b12d6ec950cc456

'}, {'number': 11, 'created': '2014-01-23 15:49:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/c4d9f2e1e29119268cbaee3a8a420846341c4e29', 'message': 'Multiversion authentication part1

WIP - do not merge

Moves authentication from rest_client to an external
auth_provider, assigned to the client by the client
manager.

The auth provider can decorate a request based on
credentials (coming from the client manager) and filters
 (region, service, endpoint_type) given by the client.
The auth provider can also return the raw auth_data,
which in the Keystone implementation is a tuple
(token, auth_data).
The auth provider allows mixing multiple credentials
when decorating a request, possibly using empty or
invalid credentials, to facilitate negative tests.

The auth provider caches auth data, so that all API
requests for a specific set of credentials only require
a single call to obtain a token, unless the token
expires or is forcefully deleted from the auth provder.

Two implementations of the auth provider are included:
Keystonev2 and Keystonev3.  The Manager object behaves
as factory of auth_providers, building the correct one
based on the configured auth_version, and on the
interafce type (JSON or XML).

Fixes endpoint_type selection for v3 auth.
Drops unused basic_auth.
Extends TokenClients into AuthClienats to provide both token
and auth data, as well as accept XML reply for XML requests.
Removes redundant server_client_v3_auth.

Adapts tempest unit tests to work with modified rest client.

Introduces a configuration parameter for
authentication version to be used. That is used when
instantiating the client manager, and it applies
to all clients used by api tests.

Next steps (next patches):
- move to credentials as dict (as opposed to tuple)
- expose a get_client method from the client manager
  and create clients only when requested
- remove redundant CustomizedHeader object storage clients
- supports keystone v3 in tenant isolation
- use Auth Provider in scenario tests
- use Auth Provider in CLI tests

Partially implements:
bp multi-keystone-api-version-tests

Change-Id: Icfa921e9051c01f339f8d2471b12d6ec950cc456
'}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2014-01-27 14:05:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/d84c83e45b670c7858d3cf585f848116cc323508', 'message': 'Multiversion authentication part1

Moves authentication from rest_client to an external auth_provider,
assigned to the client by the client manager.

The auth provider can decorate a request based on credentials (coming
from the client manager) and filters (region, service, endpoint_type)
given by the client. The auth provider can also return the raw
auth_data, which in the Keystone implementation is a tuple (token,

when decorating a request, possibly using empty or invalid credentials,
to facilitate negative tests.

The auth provider caches auth data, so that all API requests for a
specific set of credentials only require a single call to obtain a
token, unless the token expires or is forcefully deleted from the

Two implementations of the auth provider are included: Keystonev2 and

building the correct one based on the configured auth_version, and on

Fixes endpoint selection for v3 auth. Drops unused basic_auth.
Extends TokenClients to provide both token and auth data,

- remove redundant CustomizedHeader object storage clients

- use Auth Provider in scenario tests
- use Auth Provider in CLI tests
- implement parsing of catalog XML format (?)

Partially implements: bp multi-keystone-api-version-tests

Change-Id: Icfa921e9051c01f339f8d2471b12d6ec950cc456

Keystonev3.  The Manager object behaves as factory of auth_providers,
building the correct one based on the configured auth_version, and on
the interface type (JSON or XML).

Fixes endpoint selection for v3 auth. Drops unused basic_auth.
Extends TokenClients to provide both token and auth data,
and accept different combinations of credentials for v3.
Removes redundant server_client_v3_auth.

Adapts tempest unit tests to work with modified rest client.

Introduces a configuration parameter for authentication version to be
used. That is used when instantiating the client manager, and it
applies to all clients used by api tests.

Next steps (next patches):
- move to credentials as dict (as opposed to tuple)
- expose a get_client method from the client manager
  and create clients only when requested
- remove redundant CustomizedHeader object storage clients
- supports keystone v3 in tenant isolation
- use Auth Provider in scenario tests
- use Auth Provider in CLI tests
- implement parsing of catalog XML format (?)

Partially implements: bp multi-keystone-api-version-tests

commit_message:
Multiversion authentication part1

Moves authentication from rest_client to an external auth_provider,
assigned to the client by the client manager.

The auth provider can decorate a request based on credentials (coming
from the client manager) and filters (region, service, endpoint_type)
given by the client. The auth provider can also return the raw
auth_data, which in the Keystone implementation is a tuple (token,
auth_data). The auth provider allows mixing multiple credentials
when decorating a request, possibly using empty or invalid credentials,
to facilitate negative tests.

The auth provider caches auth data, so that all API requests for a
specific set of credentials only require a single call to obtain a
token, unless the token expires or is forcefully deleted from the
auth provder.

Two implementations of the auth provider are included: Keystonev2 and
Keystonev3.  The Manager object behaves as factory of auth_providers,
building the correct one based on the configured auth_version, and on
the interface type (JSON or XML).

Fixes endpoint selection for v3 auth. Drops unused basic_auth.
Extends TokenClients to provide both token and auth data,
and accept different combinations of credentials for v3.
Removes redundant server_client_v3_auth.

Adapts tempest unit tests to work with modified rest client.

Introduces a configuration parameter for authentication version to be
used. That is used when instantiating the client manager, and it
applies to all clients used by api tests.

Next steps (next patches):
- move to credentials as dict (as opposed to tuple)
- expose a get_client method from the client manager
  and create clients only when requested
- remove redundant CustomizedHeader object storage clients
- supports keystone v3 in tenant isolation
- use Auth Provider in scenario tests
- use Auth Provider in CLI tests
- implement parsing of catalog XML format (?)

Partially implements: bp multi-keystone-api-version-tests

Change-Id: Icfa921e9051c01f339f8d2471b12d6ec950cc456

commit_message:
Make the simple_tenant_usage API use objects

This change makes the simple_tenant_usage V2 and V3 APIs use Instance
and Flavor objects.

Related to blueprint compute-manager-objects

Change-Id: I8e0e870727d687da165c809ffb7a4456bff81122
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/14/64914/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.objects import flavor as flavor_obj from nova.objects import instance as instance_obj launched_at = instance.launched_at terminated_at = instance.terminated_at terminated_at = timeutils.parse_isotime(terminated_at) launched_at = timeutils.parse_isotime(launched_at) def _get_flavor(self, context, instance, flavors_cache): return instance.get_flavor() except KeyError: if not instance.deleted: flavor_type = instance.instance_type_id flavor_ref = flavor_obj.Flavor.get_by_id(context, flavor_type) flavors_cache[flavor_type] = flavor_ref except exception.FlavorNotFound: # can't bill if there is no flavor flavor_ref = None return flavor_ref instances = instance_obj.InstanceList.get_active_by_window_joined( context, period_start, period_stop, tenant_id, expected_attrs=instance_obj.INSTANCE_DEFAULT_FIELDS) flavor = self._get_flavor(context, instance, flavors) info['instance_id'] = instance.uuid info['name'] = instance.display_name info['memory_mb'] = flavor.memory_mb info['local_gb'] = flavor.root_gb + flavor.ephemeral_gb info['vcpus'] = flavor.vcpus info['tenant_id'] = instance.project_id info['flavor'] = flavor.name # NOTE(mriedem): We need to normalize the start/end times back # to timezone-naive so the response doesn't change after the # conversion to objects. info['started_at'] = timeutils.normalize_time(instance.launched_at) info['ended_at'] = ( timeutils.normalize_time(instance.terminated_at) if instance.terminated_at else None) info['state'] = instance.vm_state summary['start'] = timeutils.normalize_time(period_start) summary['stop'] = timeutils.normalize_time(period_stop) return timeutils.parse_isotime(timeutils.strtime()) else: # NOTE(mriedem): NovaObjects are timezone-aware so we parse the # timestamp into isotime so we can compare against the Instance # object datetime fields later. return timeutils.parse_isotime(dtstr) now = timeutils.parse_isotime(timeutils.strtime()) now = timeutils.parse_isotime(timeutils.strtime())
deleted_lines: from nova.compute import api from nova.compute import flavors launched_at = instance['launched_at'] terminated_at = instance['terminated_at'] terminated_at = timeutils.parse_strtime(terminated_at, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%f") launched_at = timeutils.parse_strtime(launched_at, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%f") def _get_flavor(self, context, compute_api, instance, flavors_cache): return flavors.extract_flavor(instance) except KeyError: if not instance['deleted']: flavor_type = instance['instance_type_id'] it_ref = compute_api.get_instance_type(context, flavor_type) flavors_cache[flavor_type] = it_ref except exception.FlavorNotFound: # can't bill if there is no instance type it_ref = None return it_ref compute_api = api.API() instances = compute_api.get_active_by_window(context, period_start, period_stop, tenant_id) flavor = self._get_flavor(context, compute_api, instance, flavors) info['instance_id'] = instance['uuid'] info['name'] = instance['display_name'] info['memory_mb'] = flavor['memory_mb'] info['local_gb'] = flavor['root_gb'] + flavor['ephemeral_gb'] info['vcpus'] = flavor['vcpus'] info['tenant_id'] = instance['project_id'] info['flavor'] = flavor['name'] info['started_at'] = instance['launched_at'] info['ended_at'] = instance['terminated_at'] info['state'] = instance['vm_state'] summary['start'] = period_start summary['stop'] = period_stop return timeutils.utcnow() try: return timeutils.parse_strtime(dtstr, "%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S") except Exception: try: return timeutils.parse_strtime(dtstr, "%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S.%f") except Exception: return timeutils.parse_strtime(dtstr, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%f") now = timeutils.utcnow() now = timeutils.utcnow()

subject: Improve handling of invalid input in HashRing class
revisions:

HashRing __init__ and get_hosts shouldn't be passed None,

Closes-bug: #1274762
"}]
commit_message:
Improve handling of invalid input in HashRing class

HashRing __init__ and get_hosts shouldn't be passed None,
but if they are, an appropriate error should be raised.

Change-Id: I139e7410c43bf4ac0f3357797ad767fde9455e36
Closes-bug: #1274762
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/67/70267/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from ironic.common import exception def test_create_ring_invalid_data(self): hosts = None self.assertRaises(exception.Invalid, hash.HashRing, hosts) def test_get_hosts_invalid_data(self): hosts = ['foo', 'bar'] ring = hash.HashRing(hosts) self.assertRaises(exception.Invalid, ring.get_hosts, None)

Python 3: make tests from v2_0/test_access.py pass

making sure they are given bytes.

commit_message:
Fix import log_handler error with publish_errors set

Sync latest module log_handler from Oslo.
Commit Id is 2843a92a0e4007f50d5ad63d51fe574e1ba5e280

This handler sends the error to configured notifier.
The notifier could be any kind (log, RPC, no_op, None).

Note: when using publish_errors you also need to set the
notification_driver option too.

Closes-bug: #1240349
Change-Id: I4f759b049b8f34904ba11382a2e8fc1578677a8f
(cherry picked from commit f29f812bc64726b01a50590894d6d430c5f3d30d)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/19/69719/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from django import forms from django.forms.widgets import * # noqa from django.utils.html import format_html from itertools import chain class TableSelect(forms.widgets.Select): """A select widget using a table to display the various choices""" def render(self, name, value, attrs=None, choices=()): headers = self.headers choices = chain(self.choices, choices) attrs_str = ( ' '.join( ('%s=%s' % (a, attrs[a]) for a in attrs)) if attrs else '') + ' ' + ( ' '.join( ('%s="%s"' % (a, self.attrs[a]) for a in self.attrs)) if self.attrs else '' ).strip(' ') return format_html(''.join(( '
' % attrs_str, '' % (name, value), '\n' % name, self.render_header(headers), '\n', self.render_options(name, choices, headers, value, attrs), '
'))) def render_header(self, headers): return ''.join( '{0}'.format(header) for header in headers + ['', ]) def render_option(self, name, option, headers, attrs): _id, values = option return ''.join( '{0}'.format(values[header]) for header in headers) + self.render_validate_button( name, option, attrs) def render_options(self, name, choices, headers, value, attrs): return ''.join( '%s' % ( '-'.join((name, choice[0])), 'active' if value == choice[0] else '', self.render_option(name, choice, headers, attrs)) for choice in choices) def render_validate_button(self, name, option, attrs): return ( '' % (attrs['id'], option[0], attrs['id'], '%s-%s' % (name, option[0])) ) class TreeSelect(TableSelect): def render(self, name, value, attrs=None, choices=()): headers = self.headers choices = chain(self.choices, choices)

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-01-29 11:00:04.000000000', 'files': ['swift/account/backend.py', 'swift/common/db.py', 'swift/container/server.py', 'swift/container/backend.py', 'swift/proxy/controllers/base.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/8ab590d0c5e1db078496fb422b4b4a72ccd7bc49', 'message': '503 instead of 404 if account server fails

In certain case the proxy server returns 404 masking errors in the
account-server or/and in the container-server.
Which are these cases?
1, If the {account, container}-server do not have the correct permissions
   to access its database files, it answers with 404,
2, When making request through the container controller in the proxy-server
   and the account-server is down it answers with 404, like if the user was

In each of these cases 5xx would be more appropriate than HTTP_NOT_FOUND.

fix verifies in swift.proxy.controllers.base.Base.get_info(...) whether the

results in a 500.

commit_message:
503 instead of 404 if account server fails

In certain case the proxy server returns 404 masking errors in the
account-server or/and in the container-server.
Which are these cases?
1, If the {account, container}-server do not have the correct permissions
   to access its database files, it answers with 404,
2, When making request through the container controller in the proxy-server
   and the account-server is down it answers with 404, like if the user was
   not existing.
In each of these cases 5xx would be more appropriate than HTTP_NOT_FOUND.
This patches fixes the first case by verifying in
swift.common.db.DatabaseBroker.get(self), in
swift.account.backend.AccountBroker.is_deleted(self) and in
swift.container.backend.ContainerBroker.is_deleted(self) whether the servers
have the correct permissions, and if not, it raises a DatabaseConnectionError
with an error message indicating wrong permissions. For the second case the
fix verifies in swift.proxy.controllers.base.Base.get_info(...) whether the
response returned by either the account-server or the container server is a
5xx, and if it is, it immedietly raises an uncaught ValueError exception which
results in a 500.

Change-Id: Ib49a07c2a3cd34c82888503a356b613f777fa968
Closes-Bug: #1229382
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/76/69576/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use ip6tables iff IPv6 support is available.

Consistently setup ipv6 related rules when ipv6
is available. Removes use_ipv6 option as its value
is auto-detected now.

Change-Id: Iff4b9d5d7376b272e4a3bf7a19b4cfaa9579de9b
Closes-Bug: #1203611

added_lines: import errnoimport sys def is_ipv6_supported(): has_ipv6_support = socket.has_ipv6 try: s = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET6, socket.SOCK_STREAM) s.close() except socket.error as e: if e.errno == errno.EAFNOSUPPORT: has_ipv6_support = False else: raise # check if there is at least one interface with ipv6 if has_ipv6_support and sys.platform.startswith('linux'): try: with open('/proc/net/if_inet6') as f: if not f.read(): has_ipv6_support = False except IOError: has_ipv6_support = False return has_ipv6_support

commit_message:
Change weight_multiplier() to _weight_multiplier() for weight

In Nova, weight is using weight_multiplier() to get different weight
multipliers; In Oslo, it is using _weight_multiplier() to get
different weight multipliers. We should update Nova to change
weight_multiplier() to an internal method to keep consistent with
Oslo.

Also weight_multiplier() is an internal method for every class, so
we should set it as internal method.

This patch also removes one unused variable from
nova/tests/test_weights.py

Change-Id: Ifa1eba8368f85b80db4306089f286f01f9fc53cc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/85/66285/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _weight_multiplier(self): obj.weight += weigher._weight_multiplier() * weight
deleted_lines: def weight_multiplier(self): obj.weight += weigher.weight_multiplier() * weight

commit_message:
add bc to general RPM requirements

bc is not part of a standard Fedora 20 install and may be missing
in earlier Fedoras and RHEL as well.  A similar requirement was
added for apt-sourced packages in commit

121d65023b822fd4285d315386eedd023cbf223e

Change-Id: I371890121f82cee577dd25bea1d9bbf32ec7ec74
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/74/69874/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: bc

commit_message:
add backend info and child process id

The cinder volume service crashes when a backend is not configured
correctly or reachable. There is very little information to go on
to allow the admin identify the problem and perform the corrective
action. We have added some info to help out with this issue.

Change-Id: Ia77ed80c62e5db7464b3ef9f3f9a13eb9788328e
Signed-off-by: David Medberry <david.medberry@canonical.com>
Signed-off-by: David Medberry <openstack@medberry.net>

added_lines: signal.signal(signal.SIGUSR1, self._handle_dump_request) signal.signal(signal.SIGUSR1, signal.SIG_DFL) def _handle_dump_request(self, signo, frame): LOG.info("(isc) Signal initiated backend status output:") for child in self.children: try: wrap = self.children[child] service = wrap.server LOG.info( "Backend: %s " "(pid: %s, failed: %s, forks: %s, workers: %s)", str(service.host), str(child), str(wrap.failed), str(wrap.forktimes), str(wrap.workers)) except: LOG.info("Backend: --unknown-- (%s)", child)

commit_message:
Set content length to 0 in case of empty body

Changes rest_client to set the Content-Length HTTP header to 0
in case body is None and method is PUT/POST/PATCH.
Some HTTP servers will return 411 otherwise.

Change-Id: I304cde691a02619b2514292ec196f80a9df0d4ad
Fixes: lp 1238536
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/25/69625/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Some HTTP servers will reply 411 if the content length is not set if body is None: headers['Content-Length'] = 0

commit_message:
Sync cliutils and uuidutils from Oslo

Related to blueprint common-client-library-2

Change-Id: Ic31fca0a237aa6fbb5eefabcfe309b420b0833b7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/79/69379/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2012 Red Hat, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # W0603: Using the global statement # W0621: Redefining name %s from outer scope # pylint: disable=W0603,W0621 from __future__ import print_function import getpass import inspect import os import sys import textwrap import prettytable import six from six import moves from keystoneclient.openstack.common.apiclient import exceptions from keystoneclient.openstack.common.gettextutils import _ from keystoneclient.openstack.common import importutils from keystoneclient.openstack.common import strutils from keystoneclient.openstack.common import uuidutils def validate_args(fn, *args, **kwargs): """Check that the supplied args are sufficient for calling a function. >>> validate_args(lambda a: None) Traceback (most recent call last): ... MissingArgs: Missing argument(s): a >>> validate_args(lambda a, b, c, d: None, 0, c=1) Traceback (most recent call last): ... MissingArgs: Missing argument(s): b, d :param fn: the function to check :param arg: the positional arguments supplied :param kwargs: the keyword arguments supplied """ argspec = inspect.getargspec(fn) num_defaults = len(argspec.defaults or []) required_args = argspec.args[:len(argspec.args) - num_defaults] def isbound(method): return getattr(method, 'im_self', None) is not None if isbound(fn): required_args.pop(0) missing = [arg for arg in required_args if arg not in kwargs] missing = missing[len(args):] if missing: raise exceptions.MissingArgs(missing) def arg(*args, **kwargs): """Decorator for CLI args. Example: >>> @arg("name", help="Name of the new entity") ... def entity_create(args): ... pass """ def _decorator(func): add_arg(func, *args, **kwargs) return func return _decorator def env(*args, **kwargs): """Returns the first environment variable set. If all are empty, defaults to '' or keyword arg `default`. """ for arg in args: value = os.environ.get(arg, None) if value: return value return kwargs.get('default', '') def add_arg(func, *args, **kwargs): """Bind CLI arguments to a shell.py `do_foo` function.""" if not hasattr(func, 'arguments'): func.arguments = [] # NOTE(sirp): avoid dups that can occur when the module is shared across # tests. if (args, kwargs) not in func.arguments: # Because of the semantics of decorator composition if we just append # to the options list positional options will appear to be backwards. func.arguments.insert(0, (args, kwargs)) def unauthenticated(func): """Adds 'unauthenticated' attribute to decorated function. Usage: >>> @unauthenticated ... def mymethod(f): ... pass """ func.unauthenticated = True return func def isunauthenticated(func): """Checks if the function does not require authentication. Mark such functions with the `@unauthenticated` decorator. :returns: bool """ return getattr(func, 'unauthenticated', False) def print_list(objs, fields, formatters=None, sortby_index=0, mixed_case_fields=None): """Print a list or objects as a table, one row per object. :param objs: iterable of :class:`Resource` :param fields: attributes that correspond to columns, in order :param formatters: `dict` of callables for field formatting :param sortby_index: index of the field for sorting table rows :param mixed_case_fields: fields corresponding to object attributes that have mixed case names (e.g., 'serverId') """ formatters = formatters or {} mixed_case_fields = mixed_case_fields or [] if sortby_index is None: kwargs = {} else: kwargs = {'sortby': fields[sortby_index]} pt = prettytable.PrettyTable(fields, caching=False) pt.align = 'l' for o in objs: row = [] for field in fields: if field in formatters: row.append(formatters[field](o)) else: if field in mixed_case_fields: field_name = field.replace(' ', '_') else: field_name = field.lower().replace(' ', '_') data = getattr(o, field_name, '') row.append(data) pt.add_row(row) print(strutils.safe_encode(pt.get_string(**kwargs))) def print_dict(dct, dict_property="Property", wrap=0): """Print a `dict` as a table of two columns. :param dct: `dict` to print :param dict_property: name of the first column :param wrap: wrapping for the second column """ pt = prettytable.PrettyTable([dict_property, 'Value'], caching=False) pt.align = 'l' for k, v in six.iteritems(dct): # convert dict to str to check length if isinstance(v, dict): v = str(v) if wrap > 0: v = textwrap.fill(str(v), wrap) # if value has a newline, add in multiple rows # e.g. fault with stacktrace if v and isinstance(v, six.string_types) and r'\n' in v: lines = v.strip().split(r'\n') col1 = k for line in lines: pt.add_row([col1, line]) col1 = '' else: pt.add_row([k, v]) print(strutils.safe_encode(pt.get_string())) def get_password(max_password_prompts=3): """Read password from TTY.""" verify = strutils.bool_from_string(env("OS_VERIFY_PASSWORD")) pw = None if hasattr(sys.stdin, "isatty") and sys.stdin.isatty(): # Check for Ctrl-D try: for __ in moves.range(max_password_prompts): pw1 = getpass.getpass("OS Password: ") if verify: pw2 = getpass.getpass("Please verify: ") else: pw2 = pw1 if pw1 == pw2 and pw1: pw = pw1 break except EOFError: pass return pw def find_resource(manager, name_or_id, **find_args): """Look for resource in a given manager. Used as a helper for the _find_* methods. Example: def _find_hypervisor(cs, hypervisor): #Get a hypervisor by name or ID. return cliutils.find_resource(cs.hypervisors, hypervisor) """ # first try to get entity as integer id try: return manager.get(int(name_or_id)) except (TypeError, ValueError, exceptions.NotFound): pass # now try to get entity as uuid try: tmp_id = strutils.safe_encode(name_or_id) if uuidutils.is_uuid_like(tmp_id): return manager.get(tmp_id) except (TypeError, ValueError, exceptions.NotFound): pass # for str id which is not uuid if getattr(manager, 'is_alphanum_id_allowed', False): try: return manager.get(name_or_id) except exceptions.NotFound: pass try: try: return manager.find(human_id=name_or_id, **find_args) except exceptions.NotFound: pass # finally try to find entity by name try: resource = getattr(manager, 'resource_class', None) name_attr = resource.NAME_ATTR if resource else 'name' kwargs = {name_attr: name_or_id} kwargs.update(find_args) return manager.find(**kwargs) except exceptions.NotFound: msg = _("No %(name)s with a name or " "ID of '%(name_or_id)s' exists.") % \ { "name": manager.resource_class.__name__.lower(), "name_or_id": name_or_id } raise exceptions.CommandError(msg) except exceptions.NoUniqueMatch: msg = _("Multiple %(name)s matches found for " "'%(name_or_id)s', use an ID to be more specific.") % \ { "name": manager.resource_class.__name__.lower(), "name_or_id": name_or_id } raise exceptions.CommandError(msg) def service_type(stype): """Adds 'service_type' attribute to decorated function. Usage: @service_type('volume') def mymethod(f): ... """ def inner(f): f.service_type = stype return f return inner def get_service_type(f): """Retrieves service type from function.""" return getattr(f, 'service_type', None) def pretty_choice_list(l): return ', '.join("'%s'" % i for i in l) def import_class(import_str): """Returns a class from a string including module and class.""" mod_str, _sep, class_str = import_str.rpartition('.') __import__(mod_str) return getattr(sys.modules[mod_str], class_str) def import_versioned_module(version, submodule=None): module = 'keystoneclient.v%s' % version if submodule: module = '.'.join((module, submodule)) return importutils.import_module(module) def exit(msg=''): if msg: print (msg, file=sys.stderr) sys.exit(1)

commit_message:
Using common methods from oslo cliutils

Synchronize the cliutils from oslo to neutronclient and use
the common methods.

used common methods:
+env

partially implements blueprint common-client-library-2

Change-Id: Ie89da74bc24d53db10df06470c1614f8b1c84041

added_lines:
#!/usr/bin/python import getopt import os import shutil import subprocess import sys import tempfile # given a plan/app definition, produce images and a new plan (or heat template) inputdir = None git_url = None outputfile = 'template.yaml' def parse_args(argv): global inputdir global git_url global outputfile try: opts, args = getopt.getopt(argv, "hi:o:g:", ["idir=", "ofile=", "git_url="]) except getopt.GetoptError: print('plan-to-image.py -i <inputdir> -o <outputfile>') sys.exit(2) for opt, arg in opts: if opt == '-h': print('plan-to-image.py -i <inputdir> -o <outputfile>') sys.exit() elif opt in ("-i", "--idir"): inputdir = arg elif opt in ("-g", "--git_url"): git_url = arg elif opt in ("-o", "--ofile"): outputfile = arg def heroku_to_element(user_elem, onlyfiles): os.mkdir(os.path.join(user_elem, 'install.d')) install_file = os.path.join(user_elem, 'install.d', '70-heroku') with open(install_file, 'w+') as install: install.write('#!/bin/bash
') install.write('set -eux
') packages = ['build-essential', 'rubygems'] gems = ['foreman'] if 'requirements.txt' in onlyfiles: packages.append('python-pip') if 'pom.xml' in onlyfiles: packages.append('maven') if 'Gemfile' in onlyfiles: packages.append('rubygem-bundler') packages.append('ruby-dev') install.write('install-packages %s
' % ' '.join(packages)) install.write('gem install %s
' % ' '.join(gems)) # install the user app. app_path = os.path.join(user_elem, 'install.d', 'app') shutil.copytree(inputdir, app_path) install.write('cp -a /tmp/in_target.d/install.d/app /root/
') install.write('cd /root/app
') if 'requirements.txt' in onlyfiles: install.write('python-pip install -r requirements.txt
') if 'pom.xml' in onlyfiles: install.write('maven package
') if 'Gemfile' in onlyfiles: install.write('bundle install
') os.chmod(install_file, 0o755) def get_app_code(): global inputdir global git_url if inputdir is not None: inputdir = os.path.abspath(inputdir) else: inputdir = tempfile.mkdtemp() if git_url is not None: subprocess.call(['git', 'clone', git_url, inputdir]) parse_args(sys.argv[1:]) get_app_code() print('Input dir is "', inputdir) print('Output file is "', outputfile) onlyfiles = [f for f in os.listdir(inputdir) if os.path.isfile(os.path.join(inputdir, f))] # detect format (camp, heroku, openshift, etc...) if 'Procfile' in onlyfiles: element_name = 'heroku_app' image_name = 'fedora-32-heroku' element_dir = tempfile.mkdtemp() user_elem = os.path.join(element_dir, element_name) os.mkdir(user_elem) heroku_to_element(user_elem, onlyfiles) env = dict(os.environ) env['ELEMENTS_PATH'] = element_dir res = subprocess.Popen(['disk-image-create', '-a', 'i386', '-o', image_name, 'vm', 'fedora', element_name], env=env) res.wait() print('disk-image-create result is: %s' % res.returncode) shutil.rmtree(element_dir) print('glance image-create --name="%s" --disk-format=qcow2 ' '--container-format=bare < %s.qcow2' % (image_name, image_name))

commit_message:
replaced e.message with unicode(e)

BaseException.message has been deprecated as of Python 2.6

Not fixed openstack_dashboard/openstack/common/timeutils.py in favor
of pulling from Oslo.

Change-Id: Icb80b8550ae126a463876045a9efcf8460557883

commit_message:
Implementation of protocol-agnostic HMAC based
authentication plugin

Any new HMAC based protocols can be supported
by having a protocol specific middleware
(i.e. EC2, S3, etc).

blueprint generic-signature-validation

Change-Id: I4c04ca5b4790c25f1aedadec605f5ca0b97f6a0f

added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright 2013 OpenStack LLC # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import json from keystone import exception from keystone.common import dependency from keystone.common import logging from keystone.common import utils LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) @dependency.requires('identity_api', 'credential_api', 'trust_api') class AuthUtils(object): @classmethod def assert_project_is_enabled(cls, project_ref): # ensure the project is enabled if not project_ref.get('enabled', True): msg = _('Project is disabled: %s') % project_ref['id'] LOG.warning(msg) raise exception.Unauthorized(msg) @classmethod def assert_domain_is_enabled(cls, domain_ref): if not domain_ref.get('enabled'): msg = _('Domain is disabled: %s') % (domain_ref['id']) LOG.warning(msg) raise exception.Unauthorized(msg) @classmethod def assert_user_is_enabled(cls, user_ref): if not user_ref.get('enabled', True): msg = _('User is disabled: %s') % (user_ref['id']) LOG.warning(msg) raise exception.Unauthorized(msg) @classmethod def lookup_credential(cls, access_id, project_id): credential_id = utils.hash_access_key(access_id) creds = cls.credential_api.get_credential(credential_id) if not creds: raise exception.Unauthorized(message='Credential ' 'access key %s not ' 'found.' % access_id) if creds.get('project_id') is not None and ( creds.project_id != project_id): raise exception.Unauthorized(message='Credential ' 'project id does not ' 'match request project id ' '%s.' % project_id) return creds @classmethod def get_blob_from_credential(cls, credential): try: blob = json.loads(credential.blob) except (ValueError, TypeError): raise exception.ValidationError( message='Invalid blob in credential') if not blob or not isinstance(blob, dict): raise exception.ValidationError(attribute='blob', target='credential') return blob @classmethod def lookup_domain(cls, domain_info): domain_id = domain_info.get('id') domain_name = domain_info.get('name') domain_ref = None if not domain_id and not domain_name: raise exception.ValidationError(attribute='id or name', target='domain') try: if domain_name: domain_ref = cls.identity_api.get_domain_by_name(domain_name) else: domain_ref = cls.identity_api.get_domain(domain_id) except exception.DomainNotFound as e: LOG.exception(e) raise exception.Unauthorized(e) cls._assert_domain_is_enabled(domain_ref) return domain_ref @classmethod def lookup_project(cls, project_info): project_id = project_info.get('id') project_name = project_info.get('name') project_ref = None if not project_id and not project_name: raise exception.ValidationError(attribute='id or name', target='project') try: if project_name: if 'domain' not in project_info: raise exception.ValidationError(attribute='domain', target='project') domain_ref = cls._lookup_domain(project_info['domain']) project_ref = cls.identity_api.get_project_by_name( project_name, domain_ref['id']) else: project_ref = cls.identity_api.get_project(project_id) except exception.ProjectNotFound as e: LOG.exception(e) raise exception.Unauthorized(e) cls._assert_project_is_enabled(project_ref) return project_ref @classmethod def lookup_trust(cls, trust_info): trust_id = trust_info.get('id') if not trust_id: raise exception.ValidationError(attribute='trust_id', target='trust') trust = cls.trust_api.get_trust(trust_id) if not trust: raise exception.TrustNotFound(trust_id=trust_id) return trust @classmethod def lookup_user(cls, user_info): user_id = user_info.get('id') user_name = user_info.get('name') user_ref = None if not user_id and not user_name: raise exception.ValidationError(attribute='id or name', target='user') try: if user_name: if 'domain' not in user_info: raise exception.ValidationError(attribute='domain', target='user') domain_ref = cls._lookup_domain(user_info['domain']) user_ref = cls.identity_api.get_user_by_name( user_name, domain_ref['id']) else: user_ref = cls.identity_api.get_user(user_id) except exception.UserNotFound as e: LOG.exception(e) raise exception.Unauthorized(e) cls._assert_user_is_enabled(user_ref) return user_ref

commit_message:
Added api test case for telemetry

Added test for telemetry api 'v2/meters' and a check in
tempest/common/rest_client.py to remove extra '/' from
telemetry endpoint.

Change-Id: Ib2917af08248349a6b22e118eee8e18524e386d7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/21/68321/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright 2012 OpenStack Foundation # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import json import urllib from tempest.common.rest_client import RestClient class TelemetryClientJSON(RestClient): """ Client class Telemetry API requests """ def __init__(self, config, username, password, auth_url, tenant_name=None): super(TelemetryClientJSON, self).__init__(config, username, password, auth_url, tenant_name) self.service = self.config.telemetry.catalog_type def list_meters(self, params=None): """List all the meters.""" url = 'v2/meters' if params: url += '?%s' % urllib.urlencode(params) resp, body = self.get(url) body = json.loads(body) return resp, body

subject: Add "id" argument to the handler.update
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-04 03:47:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/solum/commit/44d1858afdfb94e7cab1d3455cab48f1ba3c4cf0', 'message': 'Add "id" argument to the handler.update

create doesn't need an id as it gets created, but the update

commit_message:
Add "id" argument to the handler.update

create doesn't need an id as it gets created, but the update
like the get and delete need to look up an object.

Change-Id: Iaae7a2067293d8fd6a35d905db68d8b1d70df9e8

commit_message:
WIP: example of git push workflow against lp-cedarish

* git server
* on push, builds slug with docker
* starts vm, loads slug, starts app

Change-Id: If809fa8bf37448ee143267a13dc1f9ca054bf5ac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/solum refs/changes/46/70446/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash DIR=`dirname $0` GIT_DIR=/opt/git # check if git user already exists id git if [ $? != 0 ]; then sudo useradd git -d /opt/git -m fi echo Prepare VM-Slug /solum/contrib/lp-cedarish/vm-slug/prepare echo Download Cedarish Image /solum/contrib/lp-cedarish/vm-slug/download-cedarish sudo mkdir -p $GIT_DIR sudo mkdir -p $GIT_DIR/admin_keys sudo chown -R git:git $GIT_DIR [[ -f ~/.ssh/id_rsa ]] || ssh-keygen -t rsa -N '' -f ~/.ssh/id_rsa sudo cp ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub $GIT_DIR/admin_keys/admin.pub sudo su git -c "$DIR/install" cd ~ echo -e "Host 127.0.0.1\n\tStrictHostKeyChecking no\n" >> ~/.ssh/config chmod 0600 ~/.ssh/config git clone git@127.0.0.1:gitolite-admin ~/gitolite-admin git config --global user.name "admin" git config --global user.email you@example.com sudo chmod 777 /var/run/docker.sock sudo usermod -a -G docker,$USER git sudo chmod 2775 /opt/solum/apps

commit_message:
WIP: docker-builder

build heroku style buildpacks and deploy apps
* on docker nova driver
* or with regular vms
* or slugs built with docker, launched on regular vms

Change-Id: Id513b03782e403be0885f06e6eb271f76f99e0fa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/solum refs/changes/11/69011/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash docker ps 2> /dev/null > /dev/null [[ $? != 0 ]] && echo "cannot talk to docker." && exit 1 if [[ -z $1 ]] || [[ -z $2 ]]; then echo "Usage: build git_url appname" exit 1 fi GIT=$1 APP=$2 [[ -d /tmp/$APP ]] && rm -rf /tmp/$APP git clone $GIT /tmp/$APP cd /tmp/$APP # Build the application slug BUILD_ID=$(git archive master | docker run -i -a stdin \ -v /opt/solum/cache:/tmp/cache:rw \ -v /opt/solum/buildpacks:/tmp/buildpacks:rw \ solum/slugbuilder) docker attach $BUILD_ID mkdir -p /opt/solum/apps/$APP docker cp $BUILD_ID:/tmp/slug.tgz /opt/solum/apps/$APP/ docker rm $BUILD_ID # Build the application image by injecting slug into runner # and push to docker-registry ( which is tied to glance ) cat << EOF > /opt/solum/apps/$APP/Dockerfile # SOLUM APP BUILDER FROM solum/slugrunner ADD slug.tgz /tmp/slug.tgz EXPOSE 5000 ENV port 5000 ENTRYPOINT ["/runner/init"] CMD ["start","web"] EOF cd /opt/solum/apps/$APP docker build -t 127.0.0.1:5042/$APP . docker push 127.0.0.1:5042/$APP .

test-requirements-py3.txt as usual.

commit_message:
Handle str not working when exceptions contain unicode

When a exception contains unicode, the usage of str() in
python 3.3 will cause an error, so try to use the native
python text_type first, and then only revert back to using
str() if that fails.

Change-Id: I4f36642453555c8e288cb67956d47bd0bcb8783f

Rename self._zk to self._client

Make the name consistent between ZkBackend and ZkConnection.

commit_message:
Use listener instead of AutoSuspendTask in test_suspend_flow

Instead of injecting engine into storage (which is not clean, not
generally possible, and is an ugly hack) tests for suspension and
resumption now use SuspendingListener which suspends engine
when task with given name reaches given state. This gives us
cleaner and more portable across engines and persistence backends
solution for testing suspension.

Change-Id: Ieca80994bf4e2b6ee3a6249b644365136858bdd0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/68/71268/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from taskflow.listeners import base as lbaseclass SuspendingListener(lbase.ListenerBase): def __init__(self, engine, task_name, task_state): super(SuspendingListener, self).__init__( engine, task_listen_for=(task_state,)) self._task_name = task_name def _task_receiver(self, state, details): if details['task_name'] == self._task_name: self._engine.suspend() flow = utils.SaveOrderTask('a') with SuspendingListener(engine, task_name='b', task_state=states.SUCCESS): engine.run() utils.SaveOrderTask('b'), with SuspendingListener(engine, task_name='b', task_state=states.SUCCESS): engine.run() utils.SaveOrderTask('b'), with SuspendingListener(engine, task_name='b', task_state=states.REVERTED): engine.run() utils.SaveOrderTask('b'), with SuspendingListener(engine, task_name='b', task_state=states.REVERTED): engine.run() utils.SaveOrderTask('b'), with SuspendingListener(engine, task_name='b', task_state=states.REVERTED): engine.run() expected_values = ['a', 'b', 'c reverted(Failure: RuntimeError: Woot!)', 'b reverted(5)'] self.assertEqual(self.values, expected_values) utils.SaveOrderTask('b') expected_values.append('a reverted(5)') self.assertEqual(self.values, expected_values) utils.SaveOrderTask('b', requires=['foo']), utils.SaveOrderTask('c') engine.storage.inject({'foo': 'bar'}) with SuspendingListener(engine, task_name='b', task_state=states.SUCCESS): engine.run() # uninject everything: {}, states.SUCCESS)
deleted_lines: class AutoSuspendingTask(utils.SaveOrderTask): def execute(self, engine): result = super(AutoSuspendingTask, self).execute() engine.suspend() return result class AutoSuspendingTaskOnRevert(utils.SaveOrderTask): def execute(self, engine): return super(AutoSuspendingTaskOnRevert, self).execute() def revert(self, engine, result, flow_failures): super(AutoSuspendingTaskOnRevert, self).revert( result=result, flow_failures=flow_failures) engine.suspend() flow = AutoSuspendingTask('a') engine.storage.inject({'engine': engine}) engine.run() AutoSuspendingTask('b'), engine.storage.inject({'engine': engine}) engine.run() AutoSuspendingTaskOnRevert('b'), engine.storage.inject({'engine': engine}) engine.run() AutoSuspendingTaskOnRevert('b'), engine.storage.inject({'engine': engine}) engine.run() AutoSuspendingTaskOnRevert('b'), engine.storage.inject({'engine': engine}) engine.run() AutoSuspendingTaskOnRevert('b') self.assertEqual( self.values, ['a', 'b', 'c reverted(Failure: RuntimeError: Woot!)', 'b reverted(5)', 'a reverted(5)']) AutoSuspendingTask('b'), utils.SaveOrderTask(name='c') engine.storage.inject({'engine': engine, 'boo': True}) engine.run() # uninject engine None, states.FAILURE)

commit_message:
Use test utils in test_suspend_flow

Use tasks from taskflow.tests.utils in test_suspend_flow instead
of having an outdated copy of them.

Change-Id: I53fad3ffd132830f806836af663ebe3804d47131
